column2: Mrs. Lucia W. Roebling, widow of the late John A. Roebling, the engineer, died on Sunday morning at the Bristol Hotel, in this city, after a protracted illness. She was the daughter of James Cooper, a wealthy civil engineer of Dublin, and his wife Catherine, daughter of Toler, Lord Chief-Justice of Ireland.

RIVERHEAD, Long Island, Dec. 29.--On Saturday night a number of the residents of Northville, Long Island, held a meeting and adopted resolutions denouncing ex-Deacon G. Mitchel Terry, who eloped with Mrs. Downs, wife of Pastor Downs, a few weeks ago, and who ...

Jennie Ellmore, the young woman who was arrested on Saturday for passing a number of forged and worthless checks for small amounts on tradesmen in this city, was before Justice O'Reilly at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday.

The announcement of a mass meeting of colored citizens to consider the present political condition in relation to the interests of their race attracted a goodly number of colored men and women to Chickering Hall last evening. About one-half of the seats were occupied when the meeting was called to order and Mr. George W. Rice chosen Chairman.

Frederick Lyneker was married a week ago to his second wife. On Friday morning he left his home, at No. 28 Elm-street, in the Eastern District of Brooklyn, went to his working place in William-street, in this city, and has not been seen since.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 29.--Gen. Sharpe, commandant at the Soldiers' Home, is anxious to have the charges against him investigated judicially, in spite of the death of Moulton, the plaintiff in the case now pending.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29.--Local detective officers are investigating what appears to be an extensive swindling scheme concocted by persons in this city.

The Directors of the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railroad held a protracted session yesterday, and voted to provide for the January interest on the divisional bonds, which amounts to $276,000. Holders of the consolidated 5 per cent. bonds will be asked to fund some-- perhaps four--of their coupons.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec. 29.--The extensive vein of mineral opened at the foot of the Shawangunk Mountain, near Ellenville, a few days ago, has shown this week still more favorable signs of developing into an inexhaustible supply of valuable ore.

Mr. C. Wenham Smith, an organist well known in musical circles, gave a recital of organ music at Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon. He played six compositions, selected from the works of Bach, Merkel, Thiele, Widor, Guilmant, and Lemmens, and...

Mr. Barney McAuley, a comedian of established popularity, furnished abundant enjoyment to a small audience at the FourteenthStreet Theatre last evening, in the character of Gilderoy Punk, a rural American of a type made familiar on the stage long ago.

The men employed at Woodruff's Stores, at the foot of Joralemon-street, Brooklyn, were informed Saturday night that on and after yesterday they would not be paid more than $1.25 per 1,000 bushels of grain shoveled as it came out of the elevator.
Gossip was not lively among politicians at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday, although there was reason for abundance of it. Every one knew that Senator Warner Miller and ...

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 29.--One anticipated result of the exposition here is an interchange of information and acquaintance that shall promote trade between the United States and the countries of Central and South America.
MADRID, Dec. 29.--Two fresh cases of cholera are reported at Toledo, one of which has proved fatal.

WARSAW, N.Y., Dec. 29.--Frank W. Tallman, an influential and wealthy farmer residing at Castile, Wyoming County, while boarding an Erie train at Warsaw station this morning, accidentally exploded a revolver in his overcoat pocket, the bullet from which entered his left side, inflicting a mortal wound.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29.--The following is the official programme for the President's reception on New Year's Day: At 11 A.M. the President will receive the members of the Cabinet and the Diplomatic Corps; at 11:15 A.M. the Chief-Justice and Associate Justices of the Supreme Court of the United States; at 11:30 A.M.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 29.--The State Board of Assessors was kept busy to-day hearing arguments by counsel of the dissatisfied railroads, who have appealed from the assessments made under the law passed last Winter.
Even the real estate lawyers and the professional searchers of titles seem to admit that the transferring of land is a needlessly cumbersome and expensive process.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29.--Friends of the measure to provide a building for the Congressional library will make another earnest effort next month to secure favorable action upon it in the House of Representatives, the Senate having passed the bill last Winter.

The wife of Police Inspector Byrnes was reading in an extension parlor at No. 59 West Ninth-street, last night, when she heard a crackling noise. It was as if fire were making headway between the party walls of her residence and No. 57 West Ninth-street. She found on examination that smoke was passing out of the rear window of the parlor floor of that house.

DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 29.--Gov. Begole has written a letter to a Detroit paper defending his course in granting pardons by the wholesale. He says: "From my experience in our prisons, where I have devoted much time.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 29.--Telegrams from Portland, Oregon, received at the Union Pacific headquarters to-day announce the cessation of the snowstorm which has prevailed for the past four days along the Columbia River bottoms.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 29.--F. B. Caloun, dealer in dry and furnishing goods, which included a small stock of jewelry, at No. 1,077 Broadway, made an assignment this morning to Attorney F. B. Skeelas. A pressure on the part of some of the creditors was the immediate ...
WHEELING, West Va., Dec. 29.--The coopers of this city, Benwood, Bellaire, and Martin's Ferry to-day determined not to accept the reduction of 50 cents per hundred kegs, and ...

The residence of Mrs. Joseph Hazelhurst, No. 114 Remsen-street, Brooklyn, was a blaze of light last evening, while she received her friends. The perfumes of rare flowers, the handsome costumes of the ladies, and the pretty music from an orchestra concealed in a bower of roses, all combined to make the reception a pleasant one.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 29.--Detectives Hayden and McCormick this afternoon arrested George Clark, Frank Brown, and Albert G. Brown in Breakey's Hotel, on West Main-street, on suspicion of being connected with a burglary in Brockport on Saturday night.

A meeting was held yesterday at the office of the Charity Organizations Society to devise the best means for relieving worthy destitute blind beggars. Among those present were F.H. Weeks, Temple Prince, W.B. Wait, and Dr. R.H. Derby.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 29.--The Post-Dispatch this afternoon publishes the result of a canvass of the manufacturing portion of the city with reference to unemployed labor. In the territory mentioned there are 542 firms or factories.

For the second time within a year the American Bible Society will part to-morrow with a lot of securities, whose income has helped along the society's work. To-morrow's sale, which Adrian H. Muller will conduct at the Exchange Salesrooms, will dispose of $40,000 in ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29.--The Chief Signal Officer has submitted to the Secretary of War charges against Assistant Adjt.-Gen. McKeever for having made derogatory remarks concerning the management of the recent arctic expeditions. The charges relate entirely to Gen. McKeever's alleged comments on the course pursued by Lieut. Greely, and no reference is made in them to what Gen. McKeever is alleged to have said of the Chief Signal Officer.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29.--A special to the Times from Wormelsdorf, Penn., says: "For several months the citizens of this village (situated near the foot of the South Mountains, a range of the Alleghanies) have been disturbed by the most unearthly yells coming from the hills.

The steamship Alaska, of the Guion Line, which arrived from Liverpool on Sunday but was detained off Sandy Hook by the fog, came up to the city yesterday. She encountered head winds during the early part of the voyage, but afterward met with more favorable weather.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 29.--The last of the meetings of the Common Council over the acceptance of the 1,500 additional shares as a release of the enormous debt owed NewHaven by the railroad was held last ...
ALBANY, Dec. 29.--The annual report of the New-York, West Shore and Buffalo Railroad Company, as made to the Railroad Commissioners and passed upon as correct by Expert Thompson, is as follows:

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 30.--The wet weather of the past few days has interfered considerably with railroad business. At the Missouri Pacific headquarters yesterday a telegram was received reporting cold weather north of here, the thermometer at Kansas City marking 5 below zero.
CHICAGO, Dec 30.--Years ago A.M. Truston was almost as well known to Chicago business men as Marshall Field is to-day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26.--Assistant United States Treasurer H.O. Graves tells a funny story in connection with the recent request of a gentleman who addressed a letter to the department inclosing a one-hundred-dollar Confederate bill, which he desired to exchange for currency:
SUAKIN, Dec. 30.--The Bishareens were defeated, many being killed, while trying to raid the town of Rowayat.
RONDOUT, N.Y., Dec. 30.--The wife of Jacob Heitzman, in the employ of the Cornell Steamboat Company, was robbed in a very bold fashion on Christmas night.

TRENTON, Dec. 30.--An opinion was filed in the Chancery Office this afternoon in the matter of the application to have Daniel Dodd and the managers of the Newark Savings Institution declared guilty of, and punished for, contempt of court for loaning and investing the funds of the bank contrary to the orders of the Court of Chancery, under which it had been operating since 1877.

A report, which appears to have had its origin out of the capital, was circulated here to-day that Representative W.F. Rogers, of Buffalo, has been fixed upon by many Democrats of the State as a candidate for the place of Public Printer.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 30.--An interesting case, which is likely to attract some attention in medical circles as well as in the minds of people generally, is reported by Dr. Paaren, the State Veterinarian.

At the regular meeting of the Board of Health yesterday Dr. Cyrus Edson, Chief of the Fourth Sanitary Division, reported that of the 17 wells in this city the water of which was condemned as being unfit for use eight had not been closed, and the attention of the Department of Public Works was called to the matter.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Dec. 30.--In an interview with Mr. Babson, the Collector of this port, some facts and figures relative to the fishing interests intimately connected with the Washington treaty were obtained.

AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 30.--An exciting incident occurred here yesterday at the hearing in the case of Watt Henry, charged with wife murder. A great crowd was in attendance, when some one noticed that the middle wall of the building was giving way.
DES MOINES, Iowa, "Dec. 30.--The enforcement of the temperance laws in Des Moines is by no means flattering to prohibition workers.
A section of the United States Navy, in the shape of the man-of-war Essex, arrived in the Lower Bay on Monday afternoon, where she was anchored.
The first Brooklyn assembly of the season took place last evening in the Art Association rooms, on Montague-street, and was largely attended.

Aldermen Michael Duffy introduced the proceedings of the Board of Aldermen yesterday with the following speech: "Mr. President, move these 'ere counsel be put outside the rail." President Kirk followed up the telling remark of his Tammany associate with this impressive observation: "The board will be in order."
WHEELING, West Va., Dec. 30.--John McSweeney, the noted Ohio criminal lawyer, was very angry in St. Clairsville to-day.

LEWES, Del., Dec. 30.--The steamship Illinois, from Liverpool, passed up at 10:30 A.M. The steamer Bermuda, (British,) from St. Kitts, 19th inst., for New-York, arrived at the Breakwater during the night with her crank shaft sprung.

In a street brawl in Mulberry-street, early on the morning of Dec. 24, Patrick Murphy stabbed in the chest August Gurlicher. The injured man was taken to Chambers-Street Hospital, where his wound was dressed.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Dec. 30.--The examination in the case of Mrs. S.T. Reynolds against her husband, in the matter of the custody of their two children, has been going on for several weeks.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 30.--A special to the State Journal from Logan says: There is a general uprising in the Hocking Valley to-night. Sheriff McCarthy, with a large posse, left here on a special train at a late hour to trace the mob.

It was reported that Superintendent McLaughlin, of the Washington Monument, had made a bet with Paul Hines, the famous baseball fielder, that he (Hines) cannot catch a baseball thrown from one of the windows of the Washington Monument.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 30.--The break among the striking miners in the Hocking Valley commenced in earnest yesterday and continued to-day, there being 75 in all who gave up the contest and accepted the rate, 50 cents per ton. Numerous applications were made to-day for work, the applicants being desirous to commence next week.

Dr. J. Milton Willians, a colored physician, living at No. 209 East One Hundred and Fifth-street, called on Dr. John T. Nagle, Registrar of Vital Statistics, yesterday, and complained that Dr. E. Elsner, a German, practicing as a physician at No. 167 East One Hundred and Third-street, had signed his name to a death certificate without authority.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30.--Gen. Sherman and Messrs. Childs and Drexel held another conference of about an hour's duration to-day with reference to the best means of securing to Gen. Grant the possession of his personal property, ...

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 30.--A dispatch from Pierre, Dakota, this morning, says Pierre is one seething mass of flame and all efforts of the citizens are unavailing to stay the fire. The wind is blowing a fierce gale and the mercury is down to 25 below zero.

Sheriff-elect Farley, of Kings County, announced his appointments yesterday as follows: Executive Clerk--Francis H. McGuire; Equity Clerk--James Langan; Auctioneer-- Thomas A. Kerrigan; Deputy Sheriffs--Charles ...
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 30.--The body of the priest whose mysterious death occurred on Monday night was conveyed to-day from the hospital to the Morgue, where the inquest was held.
Edward Morris, a Chicago jeweler, was arrested by Inspector Byrnes on the 26th of November, on a charge of fraud made through the police authorities of that city.
LONDON, Dec. 31.--The Allan Line steamer Sarmatian, Capt. Graham, from Baltimore Dec. 16 and Hali fax Dec. 22, has arrived at Moville on her way to Liverpool.

RIPON, Wis., Dec. 30.--During the last year occasional mention has been made of the horseback trip of two Wisconsin girls to California and return. ALBANY, Dec. 30.--The Morton men have recently put into practical operation a little scheme which is as amazing as it is characteristic of the politicians who conceived it.

"If one witness occupies 18 months, how long will 40 occupy?" Joseph H. Choate, entering the rooms yesterday where the Marie-Garrison case was to be heard, and where Referee Dwight was sitting in expectation of the coming lawyers, propounded this knotty problem to that gentleman.

Louis Mossback is a burly giant 6 feet and 2 inches in height, with an appearance calculated to terrify even a policeman or a prizefighter. Louis has had considerable fun and has saved some money during the last month by riding on Fourth-avenue street cars and refusing to pay his fare.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 30.--A notice for a suit for breach of contract has been served upon the manager of the Mapleson Opera Company at the instance of Mr. Fennessy, manager of Henck's Opera House, in Cincinnati.
There are texts for a great many instructive discourses in the vital statistics of a great city.

JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 30.--William Martin, who was sentenced to be hanged on Jan. 1, 1885, at Ellisville, Miss., for murder, will not be executed on the day specified, he having ap pealed to the Supreme Court. It is thought, however, that Martin will eventually hang, the evidence being very strong against him.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30.--The thirty-fourth General Assembly of Illinois will meet at Springfield Jan. 7, and the balloting for a United States Senator to succeed Gen. Logan will begin Jan. 20.

DUBLIN, Dec. 30.--A conference of Nationalists of Dublin County, the Mayor of this city presiding, was held here to-day. The principle of paying the Irish members of Parliament was approved, Mr. Clancey, ...
The sale of seats for the opening night of Harrigan Hart, at the New Park Theatre, began at the box office yesterday morning at 9 o'clock and continued until 5 in the afternoon.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 30.--Gov. Jarvis has ordered that an election be held on Jan. 15 to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Gen. Scales from Congress. James W. Reed, Congressman-elect from the district represented by Gen. Scales, will run for the unexpired term, probably without opposition.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30.--Papers in a breach of promise case have been filed in the Circuit Court by Miss Laura O'Neill, the damages sought being $5,000.

A good deal of curiosity has been excited in financial and political circles in Jersey City within the last few days by a current story that the Board of Aldermen propose to bend their energies to the making of a new Board of Finance.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 30.--The annual session of the Northwestern Traveling Men's Association was begun here to-day. The Secretary's report showed that $172,000 had been collected for death losses during the year and that $140,000 had been paid for beneficiaries.

Some little while ago THE NEW-YORK TIMES, by means of Mr. Frederic, its London correspondent, performed a very creditable journalistic feat in obtaining from that gentleman, who bravely visited the stricken city for the purpose, long cable dispatches describing the condition of Marseilles during the epidemic of cholera.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30.--Among a number of memoirs transmitted to Congress by the National Academy of Sciences is a paper prepared by Prof. Alexander Graham Bell upon the formation of a deaf variety of the human race.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30, 1884. All the executive departments will be closed at noon to-morrow and remain closed until Friday morning.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30.--The annual election of officers of the Chicago Board of Trade occurs Jan. 5. This afternoon a caucus was held on the floor of 'Change at which E. Nelson Blake was nominated for President and J.H. Milne for Second Vice-President.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 30.--George Clark, the desperado who shot himself in the office of the Chief of Police yesterday, died at noon to-day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30.--Representative Philip Thompson, Jr., has made use of the holiday recess in a way that seems likely to make him extremely popular with the whisky men of his State and of the country.
Herr Adolph Sonnenthal, a prominent German actor, connected with the Imperial Burg Theatre in Vienna, is coming to this city in March to play a two weeks' engagement at the Thalia Theatre.

OTTAWA, Dec. 30.--The millers of the Northwestern Territory are all closing their flour mills, and they report to the Government that they are unable to compete with Minnesota millers who are now sending flour into Manitoba and the Northwest.
The third annual exhibition of the NewYork Fanciers' Club will be held in MadisonSquare Garden during the entire week, beginning Feb. 4 and ending Feb. 11.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 30.--Information has been received here that on Saturday last Mr. James Parker, member of the Senate of North Carolina, was stopped on the road in Gates County by two colored highwaymen, who demanded his money. Mr. Parker gave up his money, about $60, and then turning upon them shot the two assailants, killing one and seriously wounding the other.

ALBANY, Dec. 30.--The name of Aaron J. Vanderpoel was urged to-day for the Cabinet position of Attorney-General by a committee consisting of Nelson J. Waterbury F.R. Coudert, and Nelson Smith.
OTTUMWA, Iowa, Dec. 30.--Pleasant Anderson was hanged by eight masked men last night near the town of Blakesburg, in this county, 15 miles west of here.

Judge Van Brunt, of the Supreme Court, handed down a decision yesterday overruling the demurrer which had been interposed by Theodore Seligman to the amended complaint in the action brought by Ralph L. Anderton, Jr., in behalf of the stockholders of the Casino corporation against Rudolph Aronson and other Directors wherein mismanagement on their part was charged.

When Undertaker Tracy went to Health Commissioner Raymond, of Brooklyn, yesterday morning for a permit to bury the body of Malachi Daly, who died at his home, No. 608 Jefferson-street, early Monday morning, it was refused on the ground that the case was one requiring an investigation by the Coroner.

At present the children in the public schools are required to devote 100 minutes every week to reciting their lessons in the French and the German languages, divided into four recitations of 25 minutes each.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 30.--C.M. Dennison, a leading stalwart of Utica, spent an hour in this city this afternoon interviewing local politicians.
MADRID, Dec. 30.--Every fresh detail received from the districts in which the earthquake shook was severest adds new horror to the great calamity.

QUEBEC, Dec. 30.--It is said that M. Frechette, the "Laurentian Poet," will shortly be decorated with Spanish honors on account of his having written a poem in favor of the King of Spain and protesting against the insults offered to the King while passing through Paris. This poem was read before the Royal Society, and was forwarded to the King by Count Premio Real, of Quebec.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 30.--Ben Dilley is the proprietor of a well-known drinking place in this city. It is his custom each year to place a glass box on his drinking bar about holiday time and solicit contributions from those of his customers who are inclined to give.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30.--As one result of yesterday's meeting of representatives of the Eastern lines to close the agreement drawn up a week ago, whereby passenger rates were to be regulated during the coming year, scalpers offered to-day Grand Trunk tickets to New-York for $12.

It has been suggested that the company should pay half of the interest in cash and fund the remainder.
"Lohengrin" will be the opera at the Metropolitan this evening. Private letters from Italy set forth that Mme. Etelka Gerster is now completely restored to health.

PARIS, Dec. 30.--Official advices from Tonquin report that the French forces advanced from Tuyen-Quan, met the Chinese forces, and defeated them, inflicting severe losses upon them. The French loss was trifling.

SHAMOKIN, Penn., Dec. 30.--The facts of a tragedy at Klingerstown, 14 miles from here, have just come to hand. In a quarrel at Heckman's tavern at that place last night Henry Breist, aged 21, shot and killed his father, Emanuel Breist, one of the wealthiest farmers in the Mahantongo Valley.

LOGANSPORT, Ind., Dec. 30.--For the second time in two years Kentland, Newton County, this State, was visited by a disastrous fire yesterday morning. It originated in the business section, and was not controlled until nearly every shop and storeroom had been wiped out. The loss is estimated at from $40,000 to $50,000, mostly covered by insurance. The disaster was caused by an incendiary.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 30.--The newspaper the Evening Day coased to exist this morning, being consolidated with the Evening Dispatch. Capt. Castle is editor-in-chief. The name of the paper will still continue to be the Dispatch.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 30.--Vice-Presidentelect Hendricks was asked to-day: "Have you read Mr. Cleveland's letter to the National Civil Service Reform League."
George I. Seney sent to the Board of Directors of the East Tennessee, Virginia, and Georgia Railroad yesterday his resignation as one of their number.
VIENNA, Dec. 30.--An explosion of gunpowder occurred to-day in a gunsmith's shop at Kralup, in Bohemia, destroying three houses, killing three persons and injuring many more.
AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 30.--John S. Baker, convicted of murder in the second degree, was sentenced to the State prison for life, in the Superior Court to-day, for the murder of Mrs. Tuck.

At the handsome residence of Mrs. Mason-Jones, No. 1 East Fifty-seventh-street, last evening, there was a small dance for young people, given by the hostess in honor of Miss Lena De Trobriand Post, her great-granddaughter.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30.--A prominent officer of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company said to-day that since the beginning of December the services of about 1,000 men, including clerks, train men, and trackmen, have been dispensed with on the company's lines east of Pittsburg and Erie, making a saving to the company of about $50,000 a month. This includes 75 a clerks discharged from the company's main office in this city.

At a meeting of the Pilot Commissioners yesterday the yearly report to the Legislature was signed. This states that there are 133 licensed pilots under the control of the board, of whom all but 2 are in active service.

The Rev. Henry Ward Beecher lectured last evening in Chickering Hall upon "Evolution and Revolution," and that the popularity of the great preacher is still at its height was evinced by the fact that nearly every seat in the hall was taken and his utterances were received with the greatest enthusiasm.

At the meeting of the Police Commissioners yesterday the resolution recently adopted remanding to patrol duty all officers specially detailed to the service of private corporations and institutions was suspended so far as it relates to charitable and educational institutions.

Two points connected with the Nicaragua treaty have been noticed in the English press. One is the bearing upon it of the Clayton-Bulwer treaty; the other is the supposed change of position by this Government as to the "Monroe doctrine" with regard to the Panama Canal.
BERLIN, Dec. 30.--The formation of a Congo monarchy under a German Prince is being discussed in Court circles here.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 30.--The steamer John Romer, used as a transfer boat for the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway between Norfolk and Newport News, was sunk this morning in the harbor here by coming into collision with a mud scow.
A meeting was held yesterday afternoon of the Trustees of the American Theatre Building and Managing Company, the proprietors of the Lyceum Theatre, (now in course of erection ...

In a suit brought against the erratic Henry Prouse Cooper, before Judge Barrett in the Supreme Court, an injunction was granted on Nov. 26 restraining Cooper from in any way interfering with the workings of the firm of Henry Prouse Cooper Co., from acting as its President, or from receiving any money which might be due the company.

HUNTINGDON, Penn., Dec. 30.--The extensive bituminous coal mining and shipping firm of Meares Brothers, doing business here, has failed, with liabilities roughly estimated at $20,000. The failure was precipitated by the enforced idleness of their collieries, due principally to a lack of orders.
ALBANY, Dec. 30.--The Governor's letter, defining his attitude on the question of civil service reform, is warmly commended by the Democrats of prominence in Albany.

WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 30.--The Supreme Court, Justices Field and Allen sitting, convened in this city to-day to try Patrick Cunniff, an old man charged with the murder of Patrick McManus on the evening of July 14 last.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 30.--Ranchmen in the Canadian Northwest are suffering the loss of many of their cattle by attacks of wolves which infest the country in the vicinity of Pincher Creek. An effort to induce the Dominion Government to offer the Indians a bounty for each wolf killed having failed, the ranchmen themselves are now paying one dollar a head for each wolf destroyed.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 30.--There was a jollification in the family of "Billy" De Kaib, the colored messenger of the Common Council, ...
A young man went into the East Eighty-eighth-street police station last evening and told the Sergeant in command that he had taken laudanum, with the intention of committing suicide.
The Board of Excise on the 17th inst. sent a communication to the Police Commissioners, inclosing a list of places where, it was alleged, liquor vas sold without license.

District Attorney-elect Randolph B. Martine yesterday made the following appointments in his office: Associates--John R. Fellowes, Gunning S. Bedford, and Delancey Nicoll; Deputy Associates--James Fitzgerald and Vernon M. Davis; Recognizance Clerk and Secretary--William N. Penney.
BOSTON, Dec. 30.--Washington P. Gregg, the veteran Clerk of the Common Council, has resigned. Mr. Gregg is 82 years of age and has held his position for 42 years.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30.--A special to the Inter Ocean from Tiffin, Ohio, says: "The details of an extraordinary elopement and a ten-thousanddollar swindle have just been made public.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30.--Gen. Hazen has returned to the War Department the charges preferred against Sergt. Otto Holtnorth of having rifled Lieut. Greeley's papers, preferring not to order a court-martial, although requested to do so by the Secretary of War.

MONTREAL, Dec. 30.--Archbishop Bourget is said to be dying. Bishop Pabre has administered to him the last rites of the church. He is the oldest Bishop in America, and made himself famous by his opposition to the burial of Guibord in consecrated ground.

The commission appointed to inquire into the sanity of Patrick Hayes, the Bowery gambler who shot his wife on Broadway, near Fourth-street, Brooklyn, last October, held a session yesterday in the Kings County Court of Sessions room.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 30.--The certificate of incorporation of the American Water Gas Works Construction Company, of New-York, capital stook $1,000,000, was filed in the office of the Secretary of State on Dec. 19, 1884, and the company was organized, with William C. Bucklin, Treasurer, and Joseph H. Devoe, Secretary.
Of course, Treasurer Spinner, while in office, got hundreds of requests for his autograph, the oddest in America.

The Spanish steamship Ramon de Herrera, which was partially burned at Pier No. 18 East River on Nov. 3, has been partially rebuilt at the Poillon Yard, in Brooklyn, and her engines have been thoroughly overhauled.

The pulpit in Dr. Newman's church, at Madison-avenue and Forty-fifth-street, last evening presented an appearence that made the children of the Sunday sohool attached to the church long for the hour of 9 to come.

When Michael Eagle and his wife arrived from Ireland in Bayonne some months ago, and he secured employment at $15 per week, it was agreed between them that $5 of the weekly stipend should be put aside for a rainy day.

The death of Mr. James D. Johnson the capable and trusted young man whose efficient service for the New-York Central, and whose confidential relations with Mr. Chauncey M. Depew had made him widely known, occurred in this city, at Mr. Adam Reid's residence, in November last.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30.--S.M. Rothschild, who was arrested on a capias yesterday at the instance of New-York parties, was arrested again to-day on the application of Oppenheimer, Collins Co. The same charges of fraudulent business transactions were made against him.
DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 30.--The cut pine lumber upon Saginaw River and tributaries this year foots up 964,435,984 feet. This amount has never been exceeded, except in the years 1881 and 1882.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 30.--In December of last year Joseph J. Williams and John Pool, in Wake County, ambushed themselves for the purpose of killing Joseph Peebles because Peebles had supplanted Williams in the affections of Miss Alvarado Watkins.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Dec. 30.--Members of the South American Commission met to-day at the Mexican Exchange to receive the report of the committee from the various Exchanges on the importance of trade relations with Mexico, Central and South America, and other points of interest and value to the United States and to the countries south of this Republic.

Mr. Cleveland's letter concerning the civil service, which was published in this journal yesterday, gives most gratifying encouragement to the hope we have hitherto expressed, namely, that although the coming Administration is to be Democratic, and will therefore represent policies with which we are not ourselves in accord, it promises to be patriotic and statesmanlike.

The question of amply protecting the scholars in the public schools in case of fire, which has been repeatedly discussed at the meetings of the Board of Education for two years past, was settled at the meeting yesterday.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Dec., 30.--Coupons of the consolidated bonds of the State of Louisiana, at the reduced rate of 2 per cent. per annum, will be paid Jan. 1 at the State National Bank, New-Orleans; Bank of New-York, National Banking Association, New-York, and at the office of B. Newgass, London.

WARSAW, N.Y., Dec. 30.--Frank Tallman, of Castile, reported yesterday as being accidentally shot by the explosion of a revolver in his overcoat pocket while boarding an Erie train here, turns out to be a forger, and his death is believed to be a premeditated suicide.

What kind of a letter would Mr. BLAINE have written if he had been elected President and the Civil Service Reform League had commended the cause it represents to his patriotic care in the exercise of the great power with which the American people had intrusted him?
In the dense fog of yesterday morning four collisions occurred within rifle shot of each other on the Third and Second avenue elevated roads, and at least four persons were injured.
The legal proceedings had yesterday heighten the improbability that the Board of Aldermen will attempt to confirm Mayor EDSON'S nominations.

At about 9:15 o'clock last night Daniel Norton, who lives on the King's Bridge Road, ran excitedly into the engine house on Tenthavenue below One Hundred and Fiftyfifth-street and said that fire had broken out at the old French Military Institute, at One Hundred and Seventy-secondstreet and King's Bridge.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30.--Gov. Cleveland's letter upon the civil service has been read to-day with more interest than anything else in the newspapers, and in the departments it has been the talk of all employes, great and small.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 30.--The 4-yearold gelding Cardinal McCloskey and a yearling filly, Ursuline Nun, out of the same dam, by Longfellow, were bought to-day from J.R. McKee by W.B. Jennings, of Moberly, Mo., for $3,000. Socks, a 2-year-old gelding by Tom Sawyer, dam Actress, was bought by Jackson and ...

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 30.--The exhibitors at the World's Exposition are eagerly looking forward to a day in the early future when the official announcement will be made that the work of installation is complete and the Exposition finally ready for business. With the advent of this announcement the railroad authorities have determined upon a general and great reduction in rates. Every train brings fresh arrivals, and the city is well filled with visitors.
The libel-suit of Patrick Ford, of the Irish-World, against Patrick H. Rellihan, of Ire land's Liberator, was to have been tried before Justice White, in the Tombs Police Court, yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., Dec. 26.--Some months ago the record of a most important, interesting, and, we may say, surprising episode in American history was found slumbering in a box hidden away in a cellar connected with one of the oldest houses in Cambridge, once the property of the Murray family, and now belonging to Col. Clement Sulivane, whose mother is a Murray.

The Inter-Se Club held its first dancing class meeting of the season last evening at the Hotel Brunswick. The new class is made up of young society people who propose to give a senes of dances at the Brunswick.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 30.--The Hon. Samuel J. Randall has much reason to be proud of the reception given him to-day by the citizens of Nashville.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 31.--At Davidson College on Monday night, an old negro named Balaam Harris was sitting by his fireside surrounded by his three sons, when one of the boys, Sam Harris, rose to leave the house.
The subpoenaed Aldermen were in attendance on the Grand Jury again yesterday morning, but only Alderman Miller was examined.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31.--Gerald Eyre, the actor, is a guest at the Palmer House. At noon to-day, on being shown a dispatch from NewYork, saying that officers were looking for him with a warrant, and that he was charged with having married Miss Mollie Fuller, of the "Adonis"...

Immediately after the hearing of the motion for the appointment of a Receiver of the affairs of Brooks Dickson was adjourned from Monday until yesterday negotiations were begun for the settlement of the troubles between the three partners, Joseph Brooks, James B. Dickson, and James A. Randall.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 31.--The wheat market at Minneapolis has boomed during the past week. Prices for hard wheat and all good milling grades have advanced about 6 cents a bushel, an average of 1 cent a day. The receipts have been very light, aggregating only 398,500 bushels, against 644,000 bushels last week.

Mme. Ristori will appear as Lady Macbeth at the Star Theatre to-morrow evening. Mr. John A. Mackey, Miss Ida Mulle, and Rice's Surprise Party will appear at the Comedy Theatre next week in Charles H. Hoyt's musical farce called "A Bottle of Ink."

DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 31.--Mrs. Mary E. Cody, stepdaughter of Sol White, a prominent Canadian politician and member of Parliament, was arrested here this morning for forging her mother's name to a note for $250 and getting the money thereon from the First National Bank of this city.

Annie Marx, a good-looking young Jewess, who says that she has no home and no friends, was brought to the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday by Detective Phillips, of the Control Office, and was charged with intending...

Mr. Francis A. Fuller, the proprietor of a store for the sale of Japanese goods, at No. 138 Fifth-avenue, who lives at No. 225 West Twentyfirst-street, came to the Jefferson Market Police Court on Tuesday and made application for a...

To the historian of the world's progress, whether writing now or with the advantage of truer perspective which comes with lapse of years, the most conspicuous and important event of the year 1884 is the overthrow of the Republican Party in the United States after a twenty-four years lease of power.

QUEBEC, Dec. 31.--G.A. Lapointe, of Quebec, has won the grand medal, the first prize offered for the best poem by the Societe Artistique Litteraire et Agronomique, of Paris. The author was the only Canadian competitor, and his work surpassed that of 20 others.

The Norfolk and Western Railroad Company has issued a statement showing that for the 11 months ending Nov. 30, 1884, the gross earnings of the road were $2,464,049, the expenses $1,385,370, and the net earnings $1,078,679, a decrease of $138,434 from the earnings of the corresponding period in 1883.
BOSTON, Dec. 31.--Jacob Greener, of Elmira, N.Y., who claims that he holds a patent for the mechanism known as the "soft pedal" in pianofortes, and has notified all piano manufacturers...
Mr. Thomas B. Reed, of Maine, has made some remarks about Gov. Cleveland that are not uninteresting.

The feeling of all good citizens with regard to the proceedings in the Board of Aldermen yesterday must be one of relief that it was the last day on which the Aldermen would be permitted to betray the interests they were elected to protect. We have generally had such security for the public welfare as is afforded...
The Finance Committee of the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railroad issued their report in circular form yesterday. It is substantially as follows:

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 31.--Full details are just at hand of the lynching of Pleasant Anderson on Monday night near Blakesburg, Wapello County. Two years ago Chris McAllister, who suspected the solvency of a bank at Albia, withdrew $12,000, and not long after left it with an Ottumwa bank.

MADRID, Dec. 31.--Further earthquake shocks were experienced yesterday at Velez Malaga, a city of 13,000 people, a few miles from Malaga. The shocks were of much violence and many houses that had been previously damaged were utterly de stroyed.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 31.--The officers of the Hocking Valley Railway and Coal Exchange report everything quiet in the valley this morning, though they express the opinion that there will be some trouble to-night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31.--In accordance with a joint resolution of Congress the Public Printer has published a volume of matter furnished him by Prof. Spencer F. Baird, United States Commissioner of Fish and Fisheries, relative to new observations, discoveries, and applications connected with fish culture and the fisheries.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Dec. 31.--A three days' tournament of the New-York and Pennsylvania Chess Association closed in this city to-night.
A roughly dressed young man, wearing a long light ulster and a black slouch hat, entered the office of Superintendent Wailing at Police Headquarters yesterday, and asked for a private interview.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 31.--A special from Bloomington, Ill., says: "The Rev. C.S. Smith, the distinguished Illinois colored orator, and...
After ending their year's labor last evening the employes of R.J. Wright, the hay and feed dealer, of No. 916 Second-avenue, presented their employer with a handsome gold badge.

HONG KONG, Dec. 31.--Two French ships have gone to Corea. No blockading ships are at Taiwan, on the southwestern coast of Formosa, so that intercourse with that port is unobstructed. Blockade running with the ports on the northern coast is active.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 31.--Mr. Randall and party left the Maxwell House at 10 o'clock this morning and proceeded in carriages to Vanderbilt University, where they...

While Mr. E.L. Jardine's family were at supper in their residence, at Rye, last evening, a burglar climbed up the trellis to a second-story window, which he entered, and going through several rooms, succeeded in finding and carrying away about $200 worth of jewelry and other articles of value.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 31.--The 7:40 west-bound train on the Savannah, Florida and Western Railroad came into collision with an incoming train, 12 miles from this city, causing a serious wreck.

The steamship Bermuda, which arrived late yesterday from St. Kitts, had a slight list to one side and bore other evidences of having met with very severe weather. Capt. Fraser reports that he sailed from St. Kitts on Dec. 19 with a cargo of sugar and lime juice.
Steamship Manhattan, Stevens, West Point and Newport News, with mdse. to Old Dominion Steamship Co.
John. W. Dodd was arrested yesterday on a warrant issued by Justice Bergen at the instance of Carl Peterson. Dodd is charged with stealing two tombstones from Greenwood Cemetery.

About 40 members of the Liquor-dealers' Protective Association of the Seventh Ward were present at their quarterly meeting at No. 218 East Broadway yesterday afternoon, with Stephen McMahon as Chairman.

Officers from the Prosecutor's office made a raid last night on a gift-book store in Broad-street, near William-street, Newark, N.J., and arrested the proprieter, Albert White; M. Ryno, a clerk, and...

Another heavy fog settled down on the Bay and rivers early yesterday morning. The ferry boats were obliged to proceed with great caution, and for several hours there were constant relays. The rush on the bridge from Brooklyn was very large early in the day. The Sound boats bound this way did not venture through Hell Gate until late in the morning,

Grover Cleveland is making a record before his entrance upon the duties of President; making it under his own hand to the public and for the inspection and remembrance of the public; making it upon one of the most important questions now and permanently.
The Rev. Dr. Noah Hunt Schenck, Pastor of St. Ann's Church, on Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, whose serious illness has already been referred to in THE TIMES, is at present in a critical condition.
CHICAGO, Dec. 31.--An elegantly dressed woman stepped into C.H. Knight Co.'s jewelry store, No. 127 State-street, this afternoon and asked to see some watches.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 31.--Edward Pedlow, aged 16 years, was arrested to-day for attempting to burn down the Trinity Episcopal Church on Monday last.
THORN CREEK, Penn., Dec. 31.--Sovergne McCook, a young farmer, was married last New Year's Day. On Thanksgiving Day his wife became a mother.
WHEELING, West Va., Dec. 31.--A series of experiments are now in progress, the result of which will be awaited with interest by the scientific as well as the agricultural world.
OLEAN, N.Y., Dec. 31.--John Miller, of Port Allegany, was formerly a well-to-do citizen of that place, but became intemperate and squandered all his means.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31.--In 1881 Daniel Odon, a Cleveland fish peddler, eloped from that city with Mrs. Clara Brahl, a widow, and settled in a small lake town in Michigan. Odon left behind him a wife and eight of his nine children,

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 31.--Intelligence has reached here that the Norwegian bark Lena, from South America to Philadelphia with sugar, stranded at Hog Island on the 27th during thick weather. The vessel broke up, and eight men out of a crew of ten were lost. The vessel and cargo were a total loss.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31, 1884. It is estimated that the monthly public debt statement for December will show a decrease of about $400,000. The receipts have been light and the disbursements heavier than usual. The payments on account of pensions amount to over $8,000,000.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 31.--Great excitement exists at Union City on account of the arrest of King Henderson, colored, for murdering Thomas H. Montgomery on Christmas eve.

The event which inspires long-haired poets and hollow-checked sentimentalists with a dyspeptic melancholy, which immortalizes itself in the blighted hopes and unrequited affections annually entombed in the grave of each departing year, was welcomed around Trinity Church with the same old horrible din.

The year 1883 closed in no very cheerful way for Wall-street, but there were strong hopes that the bottom of the depression had been reached and things would be moving steadily toward improvement through the year 1884. Mr. Gould had said that 1883 was a "spook" year, people being apprehensive because it was just 10 years after the disastrous date of 1873;

A careful compilation of figures relating to the transactions in the Stock Exchange for 1884 shows that during the year nearly 96,000,000 shares of stock were dealt in, representing an aggregate value of more than $9,500,000,000.
Garrett Boice, the imprisoned ex-President of the wrecked Fifth Ward Savings Bank in Jersey City, was taken from State prison...

The lifeless body of Carl Pesch, a Polander, 35 years of age, was found hanging on Read's Dock, Yonkers, early yesterday morning by some of the employes of Read's sugar mill, which is situated on the dock.
WHEELING, West Va., Dec. 31.--The excitement at Fulton, a small town three miles east of this city, over the recent robberies has culminated in a display of arms that is surprising.

Solomon H. Greenbaum, wholesale dealer in jewelry at No. 525 Broadway, made an assignment yesterday to Joseph L. Scherer, giving preferences for $7,238, the largest being to Sulzbacher, Gruterman Wedeles, $4,400; Fannie E. Greenbaum, $2,448. He has been in business about eight years, has had several partners, and claimed a capital of $15,000.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 31.--As the schooner Lottie Beard, bound to New-Bedford from St. Helena, is several days overdue, it has given rise to apprehension on the part of some, which is not, however, shared by her owners, who believe...

There was a great deal of merriment at the Hoffman House last evening over the latest phase of municipal politics. The County Democracy people were as plentiful as eggs in Spring time, but the Tammany men were conspicuous by their absence.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 31.--There are breakers ahead in the sailing of the Onondaga tribe of Indians, and the usual tranquillity of these civilized red men has been deeply disturbed by the transactions of the last few weeks.
The copartnership of W.E. Connor Co. expired by limitation yesterday, and a notice was sent to the Stock Exchange that it had been renewed by mutual consent for one year.
KORTI, Dec. 31.--Advices from Khartoum to the end of November state that Gen. Gordon had repulsed several minor attacks and had food and ammunition for several months.

The Special Term room of the Superior Court was too small to admit the crowd of lawyers and politicians who gathered there yesterday to hear the arguments for the dissolution of the injunction granted by Judge Beach against the Mayor and Board of Aldermen on Tuesday, and at 11 o'clock Judge Truax transferred his court to the room set apart for Part II.

ATLANTA, Dec. 31.--On the banks of the Chattahoochee River, near this city, and just on the outer edge of the Confederate earthworks, there stands an old-fashioned log house of superior style, which has quite a curious history. It was built in 1835 by a Cherokee chief, who planted around it a large number of apple trees,
The following miscellaneous sales were made at public auction by Adrian H. Muller Son in the Exchange salesroom, No. 111 Broadway, yesterday:
CHERRY GROVE, Penn., Dec. 31.--William Martin, a farmer living in an isolated part of Forest County, drove, with his wife, late Monday afternoon to attend a donation party several miles distant.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31.--In the case of the bankrupt firm of Rothschild Co., H.B. Claflin Co. filed a bill in replevin yesterday for $42,000 worth of goods. Otto Meyer Co., of New-York, came in with a claim of $8,325, and Asher L. Phillips with one for $961.

The gentlemen who have associated their names with the perennial case of Peter Marie against Cornelius K. Garrison sat yesterday before Referee Dwight in perfect silence long after the hour of commencement had arrived. They were waiting for "Lord Roscoe," as Mr. Choate said, who had just returned from Washington.
Several hundred ladies looked down from the broad gallery in the Produce Exchange upon a merry scene yesterday afternoon.

AUBURN, N.Y., Dec. 31.--The statement of Auburn Prison for the month of December shows a deficiency of $2,750. Only 488 out of 807 convicts are on contract labor, and the new year will begin with 150 less contract workers. The State shoe shop has been started, and if the goods are disposed of at a profit 250 men will be employed in the course of time.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 31.--The United States Commission on Central and South American trade will sail to-morrow morning on the Morgan steamship Hutchinson for Havana. Thence the Commission will go to Venezuela and Colombia, and thence to the Central American States. They do not expect to return to the United States before April.
CHICAGO, Dec. 31.--William J. Gallagher appeared before Commissioner Hoyne this morning to-answer to the charge of forging the poll book and tally sheet of the Second Precinct of the Eighteenth Ward,
WORCESTER Mass., Dec. 31.--Dwight P. Allen and Walter Bennett, of Sturbridge, were drowned on Tuesday by breaking through the ice.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31.--Leave of absence for two months has been granted First Lieut. Charles B. Ewing, Assistant Surgeon; Capt. A.C. Girard, Assistant Surgeon, has been relieved from duty in the Department of the Missouri and ordered to report in person to the Commanding General Department of the East for assignment to duty.

The Tenement House Commission listened attentively yesterday to the very comprehensive report made by their Chief Inspector, F.N. Owen. He began with four assistants on the 28th July and ended on the 12th November. During this time there were inspected 968 houses with 8,811 families of 37,114 persons. Mr. Owen classed the buildings as follows:
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 31.--About 5 o'clock this evening Mrs. Robert Cordes, wife of the Deputy Police Clerk, attempted to build a fire in the kitchen stove at her home, No. 23 Middle-street.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31.--The Receivers of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company held a meeting to-day, and resolved to meet all the interest obligations of the Central Railroad Company of New-Jersey falling due to-morrow.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES calls attention to a notable development in politics since election when it refers to the case of some prominent Republicans known to it whose reflections upon the probable policy of Cleveland, as well as upon...
A fast mail train on the Pennsylvania Railroad ran into a passenger train on the Lehigh Valley Railroad yesterday morning, near a block station in the West Meadows.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 31.--Judgement was taken to-day on notes amounting to $11,108.33 in the United States court by Isaac Q. Burr, of Massachusetts, against the Louisville, Evansville...
An English Society for the Conversion of the Jews announces as the result of its last year's work the conversion of four Jews at an average cost of about $21,000 each.
The Baltimore and Ohio Telegraph Company begins the new year by sweeping reductions in its rates.

Clerk Nieglutch, of Castle Garden, yesterday received a letter from a German physician asking if a wife could not be found for him at Castle Garden. He said that he wished her to be about 33 years of age, nice looking, and well off. He would prefer to have her come to Germany, although if she insisted upon it he would settle in America. He represented himself as well-to-do, fine looking, and agreeable.

BOSTON, Dec. 31.--"Mr. Treadwell, will you give me the true inwardness of the Mapleson-Bassetti trouble?" The question was addressed to Counselor John P. Treadwell, in his private office in the Sears Building to-day, and that gentleman immediately responded with a smile: "Certainly; although, really, there is no story to make of the matter."

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 31.--The mail and express train on the North Carolina Railroad was fired into near Durham on Saturday last. The gun was aimed at the engineer, and the ball struck the cab of the engine and broke out the glass.
MADRID, Dec. 31.--The cholera has not entirely disappeared. At Toledo yesterday three fresh cases and one death were reported.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 31.--Henry J. Hunter, one of the owners of Beveridge's brewery, is missing, and it is feared that he has been drowned in the Hudson. There is no reason to suppose that he has committed suicide.

The reception given to Mr. CLEVELAND'S letter is hardly less noteworthy than the letter itself. In the first place, there is scarcely a perceptible dissent from the doctrines it lays down or the spirit it expresses from any Democratic source, nor is there any attempt among the Democrats to explain away its significance.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 31.--A strange story was told here to-day by a trustworthy negro from Johnston County concerning the lynching of Smith and Davis at Clayton a week ago. Two leading colored men were on their way to consult with Gov. Jarvis for the purpose of having a reward offered for the lynchers when they met the Johnston County negro.

The Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association yesterday completed the fourth year of its existence. It is with pride that the officers point to the record of the organization from the beginning, showing, as it does, a remarkable increase in the volume of business and a steady enlargement of its field.

Poultry was never so plentiful at this season in any previous year as at present. Larger quantities than were ever before known have been coming to this market for several weeks by railroad, steamboat, and steamship, The supply of turkeys is enormous.

Charles P. Miller, in the injunction proceedings before Judge Truax yesterday, presented an affidavit in regard to the deals between the Aldermen and Mayor, the contents of which are of a startling nature. Judge Truax, however, declined to receive this.

Henry Mueller, 28 years old, who was employed in Henry Elias's brewery, in East Fifty-fourth-street, killed himself with a pistol last night at his home, No. 1,030 First-avenue. He was married, but had no children.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 31.--In Pitt County on Friday last Needham Whitley, colored, and William Elks, white, got into a dispute about 15 cents which the negro owed Elks. Hot words passed, a fight ensued, and Whitley struck Elks on the head with a black gum pole and killed him. The murderer escaped.
A petition was yesterday handed to District Attorney Randolph B. Martine urging the appointment of Frank Oliver to the vacant position of Assistant District Attorney.

The year just closed has been marked by great activity in the religious world. There has been no more doctrinal controversy than usual, perhaps less; but important conferences have been held, new movements set on foot, and much effective work done.
Tom Sing, the Chinaman who was arrested in New-York a day or two ago for having gagged, robbed, and beaten Charlie Wing Hang, a Newark laundryman, has confessed his guilt.

Christ Church, at Fifth-avenue and Thirty-fifth-street, was the scene of a brilliant wedding last evening, Miss Mary Raymond Shipman, daughter of the Rev. Dr. Jacob S. Shipman, Rector of the church, being married to Mr. William Shankland Andrews, son of ChiefJustice Andrews, of Syracuse, N.Y. The attendance at the church of friends and acquaintances of the bride was very large.

BRADFORD, Penn., Dec. 31.--The decision in a contested election case, which has created wide interest throughout the State owing to the peculiar grounds on which the contest was brought and to the possible emergencies that may arise if the decision is in favor of the contestants, is awaited with considerable anxiety in the Butler Judicial District.

The New-Jersey and Brooklyn annex boat Annex No. 2 broke her rudder yesterday while rounding the Battery on her way to Jewell's Wharf. She put into the Castle Garden wharf, and was afterward towed to Jersey City. The boats of this line ceased running for the remainder of the Winter season last evening. They will resume running, however, in April.

WATERTOWN, Dakota, Dec. 31.--Charles S. Campbell, Probate Judge of this county, left Watertown recently and has not returned. Disclosures in his office now indicate that he is an embezzler to the extent of $4,000. It is thought that he had nearly $3,000 with him. Wine, women, and cards are the causes of his downfall.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 31.--After two days of rain and high temperature, another cold change set in early this morning, and the mercury has fallen from 65 yesterday afternoon to 20 at 1 P.M. to-day, with a prospect that it will go close to zero.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 31.--The Summer residents and the colony of cottagers who are spending the Winter here gave a grand ball tonight at the Casino, which was especially opened for the occasion. The ball was in every respect a brilliant and successful affair, and was in keeping with the entertainments given at that aristocratic resort during the Summer season.

WATERBURY, Conn., Dec. 31.--An injunction was issued yesterday against Henry Bergh restraining him as Executor from disposing of any of the property of the late Miss Carrie Wilton, who lost her life in the Rocky Mountains, under a penalty of $200,000. The plaintiff gives bonds of $5,000 to insure against any loss resulting. The injunction is returnable Feb. 2.
NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 31.--The receipts of cotton at Norfolk for the last four months were 436,732 bales, against 431,547 bales for the corresponding period last year.

The festivities of New Year's Eve, the inclement weather, and the fact that "Loheugrin" has been pretty frequently given this season exercised no adverse influence upon the numbers of the assemblage at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening, and the auditorium was filled in every part.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 31.--The Hon. B. Platt Carpenter, Governor of Montana, left for Helena to-night. Before his departure a number of prominent persons of both parties bade him adieu.

Among the passengers who sailed yesterday for Liverpool on the Cunard steamship Aurauia were the Viscountess Milton, the Hon. W. Vernon, the Rev. E. Harcourt Vernon, Capt. R. Wynne Roberts, the Rev. Charles G. Maturin, R. de Cordova, W. Brodrick-Cloeta, and Henry F. Gillig. Among those who sailed for Havre on the French steamship Labrador were Lieut. Charles P. Robid, of Brest, France, and M. Leconte, Chancellor of the French Consulate at Newcastle.
By the terms of the Postal convention recently entered into between the United States and Mexico, its provisions were to go into effect to-morrow.
The Bergen County Coroner's jury in the case of Abram Gurnee, killed by Sandford Sisco on Dec. 23, have returned a verdict of willful and malicious murder against the negro.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 31.--Congressman W.R. Morrison has been visiting here. He is, according to good authority, now a candidate for Senatorial honors.
Mayor Edson did not go to his Fordham home Tuesday evening, but spent the night in the city.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31.--The Grand Jury to-day found true bills of indictment against William T. and Lewis J. Ladner, the suspended bankers, charging them with embezzlement in a number of cases.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 31.--Since the killing of three men in the Ray mica, mine in Mitchell County last Spring, a man named Ray has been sleeping in the mouth of the shaft in order to retain possession, there being a controversy as to the ownership of the mine.
President Arthur's fourth New Year's reception at the White House will take place according to the previously published programme.

The annual report of Bradstreet's received yesterday shows that the year which has just closed has been a very disastrous one in point of failures in business throughout the country. The rooms of the Authors Club were ablaze last night with the full power of chandeliers, while flowers and graceful festoons decorated the mantels, windows, and corners.

WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 31.--The trial of Patrick Cunniff for the murder of Patrick McManus resulted to-day in a verdict of guilty of murder in the second degree, and the defendant was sentenced to State prison for life--one day solitary and the residue at hard labor.

BOSTON, Dec. 31. --Mme. Scalchi made her first appearance to-night with Col. Mapleson's opera company at the Boston Theatre in "Il Trovatore" as Azucena, in the presence of a large and enthusiastic audience. She was warmly received and was frequently called before the curtain. Signor Cardinali, the tenor, repeated his New-York success.

John Lawrence Sullivan, champion thumper of the world, sank from his dignity as a show pitcher on a baseball nine to the position of a common actor last night. He kindly con sented to appear on the stage of the Academy of Music in Brooklyn in the concert hall scene in the "Lottery of Life."
The death yesterday afternoon, at the Ashland House, in Fourth-avenue, of A.P. Bloomfield is ascribed to accidental suffocation by illuminating gas.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 31.--J.B. McCullagh, editor of the Globe-Democrat, in an interview yes terday, alleged that he had proof that John P. St. John, the late Prohibition candidate for President, had sold out to the Democrats. This afternoon Gov. St. John publishes a card in which he says, among other things:

What does it profit the people here that the American Government forwards mail to Great Britain by the fastest steamers afloat' if no attention is paid on this side to holding the gain in time thus made?

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 31.--The first candidate for the Speakership to camp down in the Delavan was Assemblyman William T. O'Neil, or Franklin County, who arrived on a morning train.
Assistant United States Treasurer Thomas C. Acton has had the responsible charge of more actual cash during the past year than any other man in the country.

It is not at all unlikely that Signor Salvini may come to America again next season. RICHBURG, N.Y., Dec. 31.--Lorin Dana, of Friendship, went hunting in the woods near that place on Monday. He was found dead in the woods during the day. The barrels of the gun he was hunting with had exploded and the breechpin and pieces of the barrel were driven through his head.

The report that the Hon. Howell E. Jackson, of Tennessee, intends resigning his seat in the United States Senate is again in circulation. We have the best possible authority for stating that Senator Jackson does not contemplate such action. He will serve out his term. Candidates who have the succession in view may shape their course accordingly.

Franklin Edson retired from the office of Mayor of New-York at midnight last night, and Alderman Kirk, President of the Board of Aldermen, became, by virtue of his position, Mayor for the shortest term known in the history of the metropolis.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 31.--Miss Annie M. Tewes, daughter of the late Joseph Tewes, a wealthy Catholic of this city, died at her mother's residence on Lombard-street, Sunday night, just after making some very peculiar arrangements for her funeral.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 31.--The loss on the fire at Jewett's barrel factory, which burned Tuesday night, aggregated over $100,000.

When the Sanitary Bureaus were closed last night there had been recorded since Dec. 31 1883, 30,527 births, 11,805 marriages, and 35,044 deaths. In 1883 there were 28,972 births, 11,566 marriages, and 33,982 deaths. Of the births 15,498 were those of boys. There were 292 twins. Of women over 45 years old 102 became mothers, and one woman over 50 years old gave birth to a child.
Mr. Edward M. Johnson, of New-York, was to-day appointed Assistant Superintendent of the Railway Mail Service under Mr. Jameson, who succeeds to the place...

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 31.--Richard Welch, of Waterford, a notorious burglar, who has been confined in jail here awaiting trial on the charge of robbing a safe in Boutwell's mill, was yesterday removed to the hospital on account of illness. During the night be escaped and is now at large.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 31.--Frederick Landa, a young man well known in art circles, was found dead, hanging from the celling of his room, at 10 o'clock this morning.

The neat little white-walled chapel of the Manhattan Mission, at No. 420 East Twentysixth-street, was filled with patrons and converts last evening in honor of the completion of the first year of its existence.

The coal combination was perfected yesterday. A meeting of the representatives of the anthracite coal-producing companies was held at the office of the Pennsylvania Coal Company, in the Washington Building. President Samuel Sloan, of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, was in the chair.

MACON, Ga., Dec. 31.--An elopement occurred here to-day that has caused much excitement. A farmer named John Bush, living near this city, had an only child, a beautiful girl. She had been receiving the attentions of a young man named Speir, her first cousin, who was ordered not to enter the house.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31.--Secretary Chandler has been able to discover no way of mitigating the order which will to-morrow throw out of employment a large number of employes of the navy.

Without reaching the high prices expected, the corner in December corn in the NewYork grain market was closed yesterday afternoon by a new departure in buying under the rule. On Saturday the option closed at 50 cents bid. On Monday the price rose to 61 cents, and on Tuesday the manipulators bid the price up 2 and 3 cents at a time to 75 cents a bushel.

NYACK, Dec. 31.--The Rockland County Agricultural Society--the old organization--has finally succeeded in holding its annual meeting.
PARIS, Dec. 31.--The Temps eulogizes the colonial policy of Prince Bismarck. It says: "It will provide an outlet for the overpopulation of Germany and for German trade and enterprise."

Mr. and Mrs. J.L. Seixas, of No. 112 West Forty-second-street, celebrated their golden wedding last evening by a reception at their home. They were married in St. Mark's-place 50 years ago, the Rev. Isaac Seixas, an uncle of the groom, performing the ceremony.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Dec. 31.--John D. Gibson, formerly a large merchant of Red Cross Landing, on the Tallahatchie River, this State, was arrested here to-day on a requisition made by Gov. Lowry, of Mississippi, at the request of Gov. Bate, of Tennessee, charging him with obtaining goods under false pretenses.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 31.--The Governor was spared a visit from "Omaha" Miller, the gentleman of several aliases from the breezy West who was reported to be on his way East for the purpose of enlisting the President-elect in the faction fight now in progress in his State.
"W.F.A."--Make application to the Postmaster. No date is set down for an examination.

Just now Queens County is overrun with members of the tramp fraternity. During the past month no less than 214 tramps have sought shelter at the Jamaica Town Hall.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 26.--"Have you heard anything about the cake that was sent to Gov. Cleveland?" said a gentleman to-day who resides in the country and transacts business in the city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1.--Representative Laird, of Nebraska, met with a severe accident while out riding to-day. His horse slipped on the pavement and fell, throwing him to the ground and falling upon him, breaking his right leg above the ankle. The physicians who attended him say he has sustained a compound fracture of the limb.

Sloss, President of the South and North Alabama Railroad Com pany and the Sloss Furnace Company; Col. Enoch Ensley, President of the Pratt Coal and Iron Company, and several other gentlemen.

There was considerable speculation yesterday whether the Pennsylvania Railroad would accept the percentage allotted to it in the an thracite coal combination. It was allowed 8 per cent. Gen. Wistar, its representative, was present on invitation of the other interests. He took no part whatever in the proceedings.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 1.--A special to the Times-Democrat, from Franklin, says: "John Baldwin, the philanthropist, died Sunday morning. His funeral was largely attended. Mr. Baldwin was the founder of a college at his former home in Ohio and of the Baldwin Seminary in this parish, largely endowing both institutions."

PRINCESS ANNE, Md., Jan. 1.--The preliminary examinations of Capt. John Williams, the oyster dredger who is charged with murdering one of his crew, Otto Meyher, was continued here to-day. Frederick Boye, the member of the crew who was captured by the Baltimore police, testified to the most atrocious cruelties practiced by Capt. Williams.

During a fracas last night in the billiard room of Ramon Xiques, in the basement of No. 95 Bleecker-street, Jose Herrera, a Cuban cigarmaker, was shot and fatally wounded by Francisco Cartillo, who is also a Cuban and a cigarmaker. The latter made his escape immediately after the shooting and is still at large.

I hear from St. Petersburg that there is much commotion in the Court set in consequence of serious differences which have arisen between the Grand Duke Sergo and his wife, the Princess Elizabeth of Hesse, second daughter of the Grand Duke of Hesse-Darmstadt.

ERIE, Penn., Jan. 1.--The crime of Polensky, the Pole, culminated to-day in murder, his mother-in-law, Mrs. Postpesch, dying of her injuries. Polonsky recently broke her skull with a chair for complaining of his drunken habits.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Jan. 1.--Another item of the business methods of B.T. Brown, the Middletown Bank man, came to fight to-day.

MACON, Ga., Jan. 1.--Jaques Johnson, so extensively known throughout the United States as the largest wholesale grocers in Georgia, have this day dissolved partnership, Mr. N. T. Johnson retiring. No cause is assigned other than the continued ill-health of Mr. Johnson. S.R. Jaques will continue to carry on the business.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Jan. 1.--A review of the business of the year 1884 in this city and State presents some interesting and valuable facts. Although the year has been by no means a prosperous one, a diminished money circulation has been about the extent of the general effect of hard times in Indianapolis.

Police Justice Duffy took his seat on the bench at the Jefferson Market Police Court at 9 o'clock yesterday morning and had disposed of all the business before him in little less than an hour.

Alderman Kirk's idea of a Corporation Counsel who "is not a politician, and who will be acceptable to the Bar and the public," was shown yesterday morning when he announced that he had "appointed" to that position Col. E.T. Wood, the Tammany Hall leader in the Twenty-fourth District.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 1.--The entire iron works at Bay View will be put in operation next Monday, and with the exception of a few days now and then when repairs are being made, will be kept going steadily, with the possible exception of the puddling department.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1.--This morning the Tribune printed its annual review of the trade and commerce of Chicago. This review has been published annually since 1868, and its careful compilation requires weeks of hard labor.

The gentlemen whose self-imposed but pleasing duty it is to explain political movements in this city had their hands full yesterday when they grappled with the confirmation of Rollin M. Squire as Commissioner of Public Works.
BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 1.--The employes of the Roxbury Carpet Factory, at Roxbury, Mass., 700 in number, struck this morning against a general reduction in wages ranging from 5 to 15 per cent.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Jan. 1.--Prof. George H. Griffith, Superintendent of Public Schools in this city, to-day received notice from Albany that he had been appointed Superintendent of all normal schools in the State at a galary of $3,000 a year and expenses.
NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 1.--Despite the drenching rain the colored people of this city celebrated Emancipation Day to-day by a parade of the military and civic societies and organizations.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 1.--The little town of Macedon, 18 miles from Rochester on the direct road east, is the scene of a tragedy most mysterious in its nature. Ordinarily that village is a very quiet place, with scarcely anything to cause a ripple of excitement.
A peculiar story about an eccentric chef has been going the round of the French papers. Felix Duryos, for some years cook in the kitchen of Louis Philippe, died recently in Paris.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 1.--Mr. R.E. Carpenter, Superintendent of the National Yellowstone Park, was interviewed here last night.

A promulgation was received only a few days ago by the Rochester branch of the Theosophical Society, from Col. H.S. Olcott, Hierophant, the President of the society. Its address was in London, where he and the founder of the society, Mme. Blavatsky, were recently visiting, if indeed they are not still there.

Upon retiring from the Bar the Hon. Flamen Ball presented to his friend and brother at the Bar, Col. Henry B. Teetor, the desk (valuable only for its historical associations) that had been in the office of Chase Ball for more than half a century.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 1.--A sensation will be caused by the publication to-morrow of an interview with Mr. Andrew Carnegie, of the Edgar Thomson Steel Works and many other industrial establishments, in which he proclaims himself a Socialist and an advocate of Socialistic principles.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1.--The report of the disappearance from Savannah of Major William H. Smyth, Paymaster in the United States Army, is the only information had here of his movements, except the later private announcement that he has been arrested in New-York and is to be brought to this city.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1.--A special to the Chronicle from San Bernardino says: "Regular trains on the California southern Railroad commenced running again to-day between San Bernardino and San Diego, after a suspension of 11 months."

The position at the time when discovered was right ascension 22 hours and 56 minutes and 54 seconds, declination month 4 1'56".

MONTREAL, Quebec, Jan. 2.--Owing to the extreme cold weather to-day everything in carnival circles is booming. Ice was cut this afternoon 14 inches in thickness. CHICAGO, Jan. 2.--The local Finance Committee of the Democratic National Convention held their final meeting to-day, and subscribed $1,100 to defray the remaining indebtedness ness. The total expenses of the convention amounted to $150,000.

The burn attached to the hotel kept by Mrs. Arthur Bunn, at Singack, six or seven miles northwest of Paterson, N.J., was burned to the ground yesterday morning about 5 o'clock. The hotel on the opposite side of the road was badly scorched by the flames.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 2.--Dr. Carver, the marksman, to-day broke a quarter of a ton of coal piece by piece, firing 638 shots in 33 minutes. It was a practice shoot preparatery to his attempt to break 60,000 glass balls in six days at the Lincoln Skating Rink, in this city, next week.

ST. PAUL. Minn., Jan. 2.--There is intense excitement at Chaska, Carver County, over the arrest of Dr. Shillock, a prominent physician of that place, charged with body snatching. Paul Shillock, the doctor's brother, and a fellow student at the Minneapolis College Hospital, it is alleged, have been overtaken by Sheriff Dutoit and a posse, and compelled to abandon a corpse which they bad in their possession.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Jan. 2.--The steamer Peter Cooper, from Annapolis, for Philadelphia, is reported sunk off Turkey Point, Chesapeake Bay. The vessel and cargo, it is said, will be a total loss. The disaster was caused by the vessel striking a sunken wreck.
Porter Cornelius Bliss, at one time connected with the New-York Herald,and one of the editors of Johnson's Encyclopedia, lies very ill, suffering from aneurism, in St. Luke's Hospital.

DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 2.--One of the powder mills at Goes station, near Xenia, was blown up this morning. Exactly how the explosion occurred no one seems to know. It was about 9:30 o'clock, and no one was in the building at the time but John Guin, aged 35, the foreman of the mill.

Mme. Ristori was seen as Lady Macbeth last evening by an audience that nearly filled the Star Theatre. Perhaps many of the persons present recalled a notable night more then 10 years ago at the old Lyceum Theatre, on Fourteenthstreet, a house with a glorious past.
CHICAGO, Jan. 2.--S.M. Rothschild, the large dry goods merchant who failed a few days ago, brought suit to-day against Otto Meyer, of the law firm of Strauss Meyer, asking for $50,000 damages.
