SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 13.--At the Solvay Process Soda Ash Works three miles west of this city at 4 o'clock this morning a large distilling vessel weighing four tons exploded, and was blown 75 feet in the air.

Judge Ingraham yesterday refused to grant an injunction to restrain the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company from paying the dividend of 1 per cent. on its capital stock which it declared on Dec. 10 and made payable to-morrow. The motion for the restraining order was made by ex-Judge William Fullerton and C.E. Rushmore, on behalf of John Newton, ...

BOSTON, Jan. 13.--The feature of the local stock market was the announcement just at the close of the morning board that the Bell Telephone Company had been granted an injunction against the Overland Company, ...

The President's social season was begun at the White House this evening by a card reception in honor of the Diplomatic Corps. Both houses of Congress and the officers of the army and navy were invited to meet the guests of the evening, and with a changed order in disposing of the crowds as they arrived the affair moved off with ease and comfort.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13.--When, on April 7, 1884, Mr. Stockslager, of Indiana, as Chairman of the Committee on Public Buildings and Grounds, induced the House under a motion for the suspension of the rules to pass a resolution in regard to the consideration of a large ...

A grand discovery is reported to have been made by a scientific person in the island of Zapatera. The island in question is situated on Lake Nicaragua, and the scientific person bears the rather general name of MEYER.

Morris Salvene, a button canvasser, employed by S.E. Simonds, of No. 42 White-street, committed suicide yesterday afternoon in the Summit Hotel at Canal-street and the Bowery, by shooting himself through the heart.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13.--The great charity ball, preparations for which have occupied the attention of society people here for several weeks, took place this evening in the armories of the First Cavalry and Battery D on the lake front, and was one of the most brilliant social affairs that has ever occurred in Chicago.

MANKATO, Minn., Jan. 13.--Ex-VicePresident Schuyler Colfax dropped dead at 10:35 this forenoon at the Omaha station, in this city. He arrived on the Milwaukee and St. Paul Road from the East at 10 o'clock, and walked to the Omaha station, a distance of three-fourths of a mile, with the thermometer 30 below zero.

The representation of "The Prophet" given at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday evening attracted the largest audience of the week. Every seat in the place was occupied, and every foot of standing room had its tenant.
It was stated yesterday that the Amsterdam holders of 120,000 shares of the Buffalo, New-York and Philadelphia Railroad stock had agreed to the assessment under the new reorganization plan.

A great variety of securities, some very good and some very bad, were sold by Adrian H. Muller Son in the Exchange Salesroom, No. 111 Broadway, yesterday. Some of the assets of the insolvent firm of M. Morgan's Sons were sold by order of Mr. William P. Dixon, the Assignee.

BERLIN, Jan. 14.--The Budget Committee of the Reichstag yesterday voted in favor of the credit of 150,000 marks ($35,700) for explorations in Central Africa asked for at the beginning of the session by Prince Bismarck.
The Paterson Co-operative Association, Limited, was started at Paterson, N.J., last May, with a capital stock of $2,400, and opened a neat and attractive grocery store in Marketstreet, near Prince.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 14.--Who was the inventor of the cotton gin? is a question not yet at rest. Among the South Carolina exhibits at New-Orleans will be the original letters patent on parchment, signed by G. Washington, President, and granted to H. Holmes, of South Carolina, for a cotton gin.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 14.--It is many years since New-Orleans has beheld so brilliant a funeral pageant as that of Robert Brewster, exSheriff and leader of the down-town Democracy, who died of the wounds inflicted Monday noon by the editor of the Mascot.
Doorman J.N. Symes, of the Twentyseventh Precinct, appeared at police trials yesterday to answer charges made by J.P. Patterson, of No. 1,160 Broad, and insisted on by Capt. Berghold.
Late yesterday afternoon Mayor Grace reappointed E. Henry Lacombe Counsel to the Corporation for the term of office expiring May 1, 1889.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 14.--There were no new developments in the strike in this city to-day, although a fresh outbreak is not unexpected at any hour. The jail and the Oliver Works have been under military surveillance since the riot of yesterday. A squad of 30 Veteran Guards from Elkhart came in last night on a special train to assist in resisting any assault.

A ladies' reception was given at the Buckingham Hotel last evening by the Northwestern Medical and Surgical Society of NewYork, on the principle, as was stated under one of the toasts, that "there is not a place on earth or heaven that has a feather's weight of worth without a woman in it."
As the duplicate electoral votes of the States of Iowa and Oregon sent by mail have not yet been received here Congressional action is needed to get them here in time for the count.

I do not imagine that many auditors who go to theatres and observe the apparent harmony which may be observed from the orchestra stalls in most companies have any particular appreciation of the sort of time which really exists behind the scenes.
The Young Men's Republican Club had a wordy time of it in electing officers last night. The talk on both sides was lively and well seasoned with club personalities.
PARIS, Jan. 14.--The Cairo correspondent of the Temps says that the Mahdi has accepted the conditions proposed by Gen. Wolseley.

VIRGINIA CITY, Nev., Jan. 14.--In the Senate to-day-, John P. Jones, for United States Senator, received 13 votes and Keating 5, Two Republicans were absent. In the Assembly Jones received 32 votes and Keating 8. Mr. Jones has already served Nevada two terms in the United States Senate.

Frederica Eichmeyer, an immigrant woman, with her child landed at Castle Garden in August last, and went to Harrisburg, Mo., where her husband had settled. On Christmas Eve her husband was killed without provocation by a man named Charles Hawkins.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14.--The leading produced markets were active to-day and stronger, after an early dash of weakness. This description applies generally, there being little of special interest in any market outside of Wheat and Provisions. The trading was more on outside account than yesteday. Provisions were more active, chiefly in Pork and Ribs, and ruled to very irregular.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 14.--Among the ex-Confederates of Maryland there are many old friends of Jeff Davis. At a meeting of the Society of the Army and Navy of the Confederate States in Maryland last night, Jeff Davis was elected an honorary member.

At the annual meeting of the Brooklyn Yacht Club, held at No. 213 Montague-street, Brooklyn, last night, the following officers were elected: Naval--Franklin Beans, Commodore; J.P. Tribken, Vice-Commodore; George P. West, Rear-Commodore; John M. Sawyer, Measurer, and Dr. W.J. Gilfillan, Surgeon. Civil--Samuel M. Whittlesey, President: Thomas R. Brown, Treasurer; William M. Moorhouse, Secretary; W.C. Allen, Judge-Advocate, and Charles W. Blossom, Charles Vanderburgh, and R.C. Hopkins, Trustees.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14.--Visitors in the Senate galleries to-day heard a brief discussion on a subject in direct contrast with that which attracted so much attention on Monday and Tuesday.
LONDON, Jan. 15.--The Town Hall at Warminster, in Wiltshire, was partially wrecked by an explosion of dynamite last night.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14.--H.P. W.H. Richmond, jewelers, of Providence, R.I., who arrived in this city to-day, were served with a summons to appear as defendants in a suit for $25,000 damages begun by Nathan Strauss, of Chicago.
The Continental steamship lines which have for some weeks past been fighting the Hamburg-American Company have reduced their steerage rates to the eastward to $14, and allow a commission of $3.
A bill has already been introduced in the Legislature to exempt from the Civil Service act of last year applicants for admission to the Police and Fire Departments.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14.--J.M. Hill, manager of Margaret Mather, and his brother, D.K. Hill, of the Chicago retail clothing house of willoughby. Hill Co., held a long conference here to-day with Charles H. McConnell, the present manager of the Haverly Theatre, and the result was that the theatre will hereafter be managed by a company with a capital stock of $200,000.

Last night's session of the Jersey City Board of Directors of Education was brought to an abrupt termination by four of the nine members present quitting the room after one of them had given the lie direct to the Chairman.

BOSTON, Jan. 14.--A crowd of Chicago grain men, several commercial travelers, and a lot of Harvard students formed a circle of interested spectators in the billiard room of Young's Hotel this evening. The centre figure of this admiring group was the celebrated John Lawrence Sullivan.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14.--So many Cattle were never before received for any day in January, the total running up to 9,500 head, and making a supply for the three days of 25,400 head. There was a full turnout of buyers and a good, strong general demand, but the excessive supply gave buyers an undoubted advantage.
HERKIMER, N.Y., Jan. 14.--The West Canada Creek, from the Mohawk River to a point above this village, is full of anchor ice, wedged in in all shorts of shapes.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 14.--Attorney-General O'Brien gave an opinion to-day reversing his former decision in the case of Police Commissioner Mason, of New-York, and allowing him to get out a writ of quo warranto and take his case into court.

Patrick Sullivan and Bernard Rourke, United States Marshals, were indicted shortly after the election of 1882 for violating the election laws, in inducing parties to register falsely in the Eighth Assembly District.
The name of "Allmanna Gja," (all men's rift,) given to one of the grimmest lava gorges of Iceland, would be remarkably appropriate at present to the Valley of the Congo.

The principal cities of the Eastern and Western States are to have an opportunity of hearing the artists now performing at the Metropolitan Opera House, under Dr. Damrosch's direction, early this Spring.

Two brokers met at the lunch counter in Delmonico's Broad-street restaurant yesterday noon. One had been an ardent Blaine man during the last campaign, and the other wore a hat won on Cleveland's success. The conversation turned upon the prevailing dullness in business.

Persons addicted to buckwheat cakes will be greatly pleased to learn that Dr. CARROLL, the Secretary of the State Board of Health, has recently examined with a microscope a quantity of the buckwheat flour of commerce, and found that it contained no buckwheat whatever, but was composed almost entirely of gypsum.
WAUPACA, Wis., Jan. 14.--Banker Meade, a bachelor, 60 years of age, was assassinated in his rooms in the rear of his bank, the morning of Oct. 7, 1882, and the place was robbed by unknown parties.
CHICAGO, Jan. 14.--The train bearing the remains of the late Hon. Schuyler Colfax arrived in this city at the Northwestern Station at, 7:10 o'clock this evening.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14.--The cozy auditorium of the National Theatre was crowded this evening, and "An American Countess," the new drama in four acts, by Mr. Howard Carroll, received its first representation under distinguished auspices.

Some days before Mr. ERWIN completed his list of Assembly committees an assurance which had previously been given in his behalf was emphatically reiterated to the effect that he was bound by no pledges or promises that would hamper his action.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14.--The Board of Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company met at noon to-day, and were in session for more than two hours.

The Police Commissioners were invited to appear before the Law Committee of the Board of Aldermen yesterday and give their views on Alderman Kerwin's resolution praying the Legislature to modify the Civil Service act so as to exempt firemen and policemen from its operations. They did not come, and the Aldermen on the committee talked the matter over between themselves. Alderman Hartman was the only man favoring the resolution.
ALBANY, Jan. 14.--This has been an Evarts day in Albany. More hard work has been done for him than has been done since Thurlow Weed supported him in the Senatorial race a score or more years ago.

WAUPACA, Wis., Jan. 14.--A week ago Thomas Walsh, one of the important witnesses in the Vandecar trial last January, was stabbed in a saloon.

Mr. A.B. Miller declared at the annual meeting of the Board of Trade and Transportation yesterday that certain persons were always lying in wait to exploit public franchises for private gain. He spoke vigorously against the proposed Broadway surface railway, and said that its construction ought not to be permitted.

Mme. Helen Hopekirk's piano recital may be attended at Steinway Hall this evening. The concert given by the New-York Trio Club in memory of their late associate, Mr. Reinhardt Richter, violinist, is to occur in the concert hall of the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday afternoon of next week.

Provided that the Broadway Surface Railroad Company will not use "spavined, ringboned, and broken down horses,"Lawson N. Fuller, the perennial debater of rapid transit topics, is willing that that company shall have the right to build and operate a railroad on Broadway.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 14.--Advices from the Temiscamingue Reserve state that the Indians are in a very destitute condition. The body of an Indian who was starved to death was found at White River.

The Rev. Dr. Charles S. Robinson, Pastor of the Memorial Presbyterian Church, writes to THE TIMES to say that his objection before the Presbytery to the proposed German Mission in East Fifty-second-street was based "on the fact ...

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14.--The newly elected Board of Managers of the Philadelphia and Reading Raitroad Company held their first session to-day. Messrs. Joseph Wharton, J.B. Lippincott, and I.V. Williamson, were appointed a Committee on Finance and Real Estate, and Messrs. Franklin A. Comly, John Wanamaker, and Robert H. Sayre a Committee on Administration and Economies.

The Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange spent more than two hours yesterday afternoon discussing the proposed amendment to the by-laws making the office of President a salaried position and requiring the President to devote his undivided attention to the affairs of the Exchange.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 14.--President-elect Clevaland this morning received at his hotel a distinguished delegation from Michigan. Among those present were the Hon. D.M. Dickinson, member of the National Committee, Detroit; ...
The annual statement of the German Insurance Company of New-York is published in THE TIMES this morning. The total assets are shown to be $4,221,336.97.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14.--Commissioner J.W. Midgeley, of the Southwestern Railway Association, returned to-day from Kansas City, having effected an arrangement for running fast live stock trains between Chicago and Kansas City.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14.--Judge Penrose, of the Orphans' Court, to-day wrestled with the account of the Executor of Sarah Ellen Smith, deceased, an eccentric philanthropist. Mrs. Smith by will left a house at No. 247 South Thirty-seventh-street to Sarah Wilson, so that the latter might have enough from the income to pay ...

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Jan. 14.--The business men of this city were to-day startled by the failure of J.B. Gregg Son, large manufacturers of boots and shoes. The firm was composed of James B. Gregg, formerly a master mechanic of the Erie Railway, and his son, a young man with small business experience.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14.--The Commissioner of Patents has rendered an important decision in the mattar of the petition filed in behalf of the inventor (Edison) to determine the status of interference heretofore declared between himself and Blake and Drawbaugh, the subject matter of the interference being the combination in a telephone of a metallic dinphragm and an elastic pad or mufiler.

SING SING, Jan. 15.--Mr. C. Loring Brace, Jr., of Minneapolis, Minn., son of C. Loring Brace, of the Children's Aid Society of New-York, was married this afternoon to Miss Louise Warner, daughter of the late Dr. Lewis Warner and granddaughter of the late Dr. Gray, the wellknown homeopathic physician.
CONSTANTINOPLE, Jan. 14.--The Porte has sent a note to the English Embassy denying the prevalence of atrocities against the Christians in Macedonia.

ALBANY, Jan. 14.--controller Chapin begins his annual report to the Legislature by saying concerning the common school fund that its deficiency of revenue continues in spite of direct appropriations from the general fund.

The Board of Education held its first meeting of this year yesterday afternoon, and the first business of the day was to elect a President for the ensuing year. Eighteen votes were east, of which 15 were for Stephen A. Walker, who has held that office for five successive terms, and he was declared re-elected.

At the weekly meeting of the Constitution Club at their rooms, No. 64 Madison-avenue, last night, Mr. John C. Welsh opened the discussion by telling what he knew of the railroad system of this country, rehearsing in detail its vicious tendencies, and advancing certain propositions which, in his opinion, would remedy the evils.

HOWELL, Mich., Jan. 14.--A Charivari party was fired into last night by some one in the house of Joseph A. Dibble, a farmer and fruit tree agent, living at Oceola, north of here, E. Mann was killed and three others injured.

Richard Traphagan, accused of keeping a gambling house at No. 1,487 Broadway, said, in the Yorkville court yesterday, that he was not the proprietor of the place, but was held by Justice Murray to answer.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 14.--Violet Anderson, the girl mentioned in this morning's New-York papers as saved from abduction by the police, and who is said to belong in Rochester, is supposed to be Kate Livingston, a girl 14 years old, living in Holly, 25 miles from here.
Hearty and frequent peals of laughter escaped from the large banquet hall at Delmonico's last night. The First Panel Sheriff's Jury were enjoying their annual reunion.
The second annual entertainment and reception of the Harlem Yacht Club will be held in the Lexington-Avenue Opera House on Tuesday evening next.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 14.--Mr. E.M. Richeson, a trustworthy, reliable gentleman of this city, who was proprietor of a wharf boat at Vicksburg, Miss., when the war broke out, this evening makes public the substance of an interview he had with Major, now General, W.T. Sherman at that period.

The presence of mind of a few officers of Myrtle Lodge, of the Ancient Legion of Honor, and of the stage carpenter of the Mount Morris Theatre, probably prevented heavy loss of life in Harlem last night. It was a gala night at the lodge.

An audience of fair size assembled in Chickering Hall last evening and applauded George Augustus Sala's lecture on "Wars and Revolutions." Mr. Sala began away back in 1848, when the reign of Louis Philippe was drawing to a close.

The theft of Lulu Darling's pet YorkShire terrier "Bright," the particular's of which have already been published in THE TIMES, was the subject of an examinatton before Justice Welde at the Jefferson Market Police Court yeterday morning.

Mayor Grace and Commissioner Squire stood talking together in the former's office yesterday afternoon, and laughed when asked concerning a published statement that a new Commissioner of Public Works was about to be appointed. "Mr. Squire and I have never had any conversation on this subject," said the Mayor.
"No fare, no ride," shouted Conductor Mahoney, who runs trains on the Far Rockaway branch of the Long Island Railroad. "If you won't pay you'll have to get off the train."

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 14.--The Democratic members of the Legislature held a caucus this afternoon to nominate a candidate for United States Senator. Mr. Joslyn, of Hartford, presided. BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 14.--An examination is being made into the accounts of Thomas H. Graham, Cashier of the Baltimore and Ohio shops at Mount Clare, and it is reported there is a shortage of about $10,000.

As the second year of the existence of the Civil Service Commission will come to an end on Friday next, the Commissioners are now busily engaged in preparing their annual report, which will be ready for presentation to Congress in a few days.

With three friends in his train youthful James B. Corbett boarded a " bob-tailed" Bleecker-street car. He had made up his mind to pay the fares of his friends. Finding a twenty-five-cent coin in one of his pockets he put it into the fare box.

George Washington Fleet brought an action yesterday in the Queens County Circuit Court, in Long Island City, against John Mackey, Jr., to recover $10,000 damages for alienating the affections of his wife, Martha Fleet. Mrs. Fleet, who is a handsome brunette, wore a sealskin sacque and diamond earrings, and diamonds also sparkled on her fingers.

PARIS, Jan. 14.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day, on M. Duval's propounding a question to the Government regarding their diplomatic and military action in the East, the order of the day was adopted by a vote of 294 to 234.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Jan. 14.--A few weeks ago Giles H. Van Voast, a Central and Hudson River Railroad engineer, died very suddenly at his home in this city, leaving property valued at from $5,000 to $10,000.
BOSTON, Jan. 14.--Judge Colt heard, this morning, in the United States Circuit Court, the case of Samuel L. Clemens (Mark Twain) against Estes Lauriat, publishers, in this city.
Friends of the Bankruptcy bill in the House of Representatives are not so wholly discouraged by their failure thus far to get a hearing for the measure as to give up all hope of success.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Jan. 14.--Menken, the Elmira murderer, has broken jail and fled. Sheriff Brown and Detective Black are out of town.
The eleventh annual reception of the New-York Division, C.V., of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, was held last evening at Tammany Hall.
HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 14.--The opposition to the re-election of Senator Cameron, what there is of it, has changed shape somewhat during the last 24 hours.

The quarterly report of Receiver Wilkinson, of the Newark Savings Institution, filed yesterday shows that he has received on the "old account" $83,885.88, and disbursed $35,978.92, leaving a balance in bank of $47,906.96.

Official notification has been received from Rome by Prior Gerhard, of St. Mary's, in Newark, N.J., of the raising of the priory to an abbey. The services attendant on the elevation will take place shortly.

The first annual statement issued by the Importers and Grocers' Exchange of this city was distributed yesterday. It shows, in a tabulated form, the amount of business transacted in the Exchange from Nov. 23, 1883, to Dec. 31, 1884.

Charles Wilson, who says he is a sugar weigher employed in this city, and living at No. 146 Eighteenth-street, South Brooklyn, yesterday related to the police at the Fifth-avenue police station, in the latter city, a story which is thrilling to a degree.
HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 14.--The Connecticut State Medical Society was formed in 1792. It was then the only body in the State having authority to confer degrees in medicine.

TRENTON, Jan. 11.--The joint meeting was a very tame affair, after the excitement of yesterday and Monday night that led up to it. Gottliebchen Blumberg, a seamstress, appeared in the Tombs Police Court yesterday. She was charged by Jacob Cocheu, a wood engraver, of No. 60 Chatham-street, with obtaining money under false pretenses.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Jan. 14.--A package containing $500 was called for and receipted by a young man named E.A. Smith at the United States Express Company's office at Addison yesterday. Soon after his departure it was ascertained that the package did not belong to Smith, ...

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 14.--Earlier than usual this year the Mississippi River has begun to rise, and as usual the responsible officials are unprepared with their levee work to resist the invasion of the floods.

ALBANY, Jan. 14.--The only business transacted by both houses to-day was the introduction of bills, and not much other business may be expected until the Senatorial question is settled. The Legislature will convene daily at 11 o'clock for the present.

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 14.--There was quite a scene in the House of Representatives to-day. If appears that Col. Thomas M. Hotlen in his canvass for the Speakership made a number of promises of Chairmanships of various committees should he be elected. He was elected and failed to keep one or more of these promises.
The nineteenth annual report of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals contains much interesting information in regard to the work of the organization.

In her long lifetime tha lady who at the time of her death was known as Mrs. Maria Mulock, was a party to much litigation, some of which resulted from controversies between herself and one of her sons. Now that she is dead her children are engaged in a suit for the possession of her estate.

A movement for the modification of the game laws of this State, among dealers in game, of which mention was made last week in THE TIMES, has finally resulted in the formation of a society entitled "The American Association for the Protection of Game, Game Dealers, and Consumers."

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 14.--The funeral of Andrew C. Gray, the Nestor of the Delaware Bar, was held at Newcastle this afternoon. Senator Bayard was one of the pall bearers, and among those in attendance were Gov. Stockley Secretary of State Causey both houses of the General Assembly, the State judiciary, and many prominent citizens. Places of business in the city were closed.

VINCENNES, Ind., Jan. 14.--A band of alleged miracle workers, who call themselves the "Holiness Band," and believe that all diseases can be cured by faith in Christ and the anointing of oil, are filling the little town of Spencer with excitement.
PARIS, Jan. 14.--The Figaro and the Gaulois state that France and Germany have come to a complete agreement in regard to the Egyptian, Chinese, and Congo questions.
At an early hour yesterday morning burglars broke into the residence of Mr. Rodney R. Lu Gar, at the corner of North-street and Lawn-avenue, New-Rochelle.
The House to-day passed the Senate bill referring the French spoliation claims to the Court of Claims for examination and report to Congress.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13.--The Union Insurance Company of this city, at its annual meeting to-day, reduced its capital to the extent of $200,000.
The annual meeting of the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association was held in the association's offices in the Bryant Building, No. 55 Liberty-street, yesterday.
The case of Frances H. Simons against the New-York Life Insurance Company was tried before Judge Cullen and a jury in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 14.--Miss NcMaster, daughter of John C. McMaster, of NewYork, was made a nun of the Carmelite Order this morning at the convent in this city. The habit was conferred by Archbishop Gibbons.

BERLIN, Jan. 14.--A shocking crime occurred at Frankfort-on-the-Main last night. A Police Commissioner named Rumpff, who had been active in the prosecution of Socialists, was found dead in front of his own house stabbed in two places. His assassin is unknown.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14.--The friends of Hernando De Soto Money, of Mississippi, think that they can make him PostmasterGeneral by impeaching the Democracy of Senator Garland.
The twenty-fifth annual sale of paintings for the benefit of the Artists' Fund Society was completed last evening at Association Hall, in Twenty-third-street.

LANCASTER, Penn., Jan. 14.--The fourth cremation at the Lancaster crematorium will take place to-morrow afternoon, when the body of Major Charles B. Brady, of the St. Louis Republican, who committed suicide on Friday night last, will be incinerated with Masonic honors.

John Roker and Adolph Pardini, two Italians, were remanded at the Tombs yesterday on a charge of robbing Felix Luigi, a fellowcountryman, of $1,600 in French and Italian gold coin by what is known as the "boodle and sachel" trick.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 14.--Judge Shipman, of the United States Court, has denied the application of the Gold and Stock Telegraph Company for an injunction to restrain the Commercial Telegraph Company from using the stock reporting instrument known as the ticker, which is claimed to be an infringement of their patent. The case was argued three weeks ago by E.M. Dickerson for the petitioner and Roscoe Conkling for the defendant.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 14.--The extension of leave of absence granted Lieut.-Col. George A. Forsyth, Fourth Cavalry, has been still further extended to Feb. 1. Major Alfred E. Bates, Paymaster, has been ordered to report to the Secretary of State on detached service. Major William F. Tucker, Jr., Paymaster, now on leave of absence in this city, will discharge the duties of Major Alfred E. Bates during the temporary absence of the latter on detached service.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15.--Immediately after the adjournment his afternoon the Democratic members of the House of Representatives held a short caucus.

GALVESTON, Texas, Jan. 15.--A dispatch to the News from Big Springs, received late last night, says that the immediate cause of Lord Aylesford's death was not, as at first stated, inflammation of the bowels, but dropsey and hardening of the liver.

J. Noble Stearns and other members of the Legislative Committee of the Council of Political Reform called on Mayor Grace yesterday and asked his indorsement of several bills they had prepared for presentation at Albany.

ONEONTA, Jan. 15.--The Grand Jury at Cooperstown yesterday found an indictment against Charles A. Knapp, of Delhi, Delaware County, and several of his companions, students of the Montreal Medical society, for grave robbery, in relieving the grave of the late David Sitterly, at Milford Centre of its occupant, and, being frightened away, leaving the body in the woods near here, as recently recorded in THE TIMES. Knapp has not yet been apprehended.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Jan. 15.--Up to a late hour to-night the situation as regards the striking railroad brakemen in this city remains practically unchanged. No movement has been made to-day looking toward the movement of the freight trains.

BRANTFORD, Ontario, Jan. 15.--There was an auction sale of Bow Park Farm, the property of the Canada West Farm Stock Association, today. The real estate, consisting of 895 acres of land, brought $71,000.
FORT SMITH, Ark., Jan 15.--A fatal affray occurred in the Cherokee Nation, a mile from this place, last evening, in which Bud Ross was shot dead by Charles Foreman.

A jury in the Supreme Court yesterday set at rest the doubts raised as to the legitimacy of the relations of William Mulock, who died in 1854, with the lady who was recognized as his wife for years before his death.

PARIS, Jan. 15.--A terrible collery explosion of fire damp occurred to-day in the great coal mine at Livin in Pas-le-Calais, France. At the time of the calamity there were fortunately only 43 men in the mine.

LONDON, Jan. 15.--A sensation was caused in London to-day by the publication of a confession by Mr. Schotz, one of the principal witnesses against Mr. Lawes, the sculptor, in the libel suit brought against him by Mr. Belt, a brother-sculptor, last Winter.
A.A. Drake and C.E. Chapman started a subscription in the Stock Exchange yesterday for the benefit of 500 needy families in the hamlet of Wortendyke, N.J.

The Commissioners of Police and Excise met yesterday morning at the Mayor's office, at Mr. Grace's suggestion, and with him discussed privately ways and means of suppressing unlicensed saloons and concert halls.

Mr. James Tillinghast retired yesterday as President of the New-York Central Sleeping Car Company (the Wagner Company.) He was succeeded by Dr. W. Seward Webb, the son-inlaw of Willinm H. Vanderbilt, Mr. Tillinghast does not leave his position as assistant to the President of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad. He leaves for New-Orleans and Florida next month, and on his return will go to Europe for six months.

Frequent thefts have been committed in the United States public stores attached to the Appraiser's Department in this city, during the last two years. Boxes of merchandise were opened and portions of the contents were abstracted in a manner that clearly indicated that the thieves were familiar with the public stores.

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 15.--Information has just been received here that Mr. P.M. Wheeler, a prominent citizen of Greensborough, was found dead in Randolph County on Sunday last at the rear of Forest's mills.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Jan. 15.--The oldest person in Niagara County died yesterday in this city from old age.

C.P. Huntington bought a seat in the Stock Exchange yesterday and thereby aroused the curiosity of all the brokers. He took the seat recently held by John R. Hatch, son of A.S. Hatch, and paid, it is said, $25,000 for it.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 15.--The Express advocates the raising of a popular fund for the relief of Gen. Grant. ALBANY, Jan. 15.--The report of Dairy Commissioner Josiah K. Brown treats chiefly of his efforts to suppress the manufacture and sale of oleomargarine in New-York City and State. THE TIMES has received $5 from H.A.T., of Troy, for Mrs. Smith, of Brooklyn. The Hon. J.M. Bailey, United States Consul at Hamburg, and F. Lincoln Wing were among the passengers by the steamship Wieland, which sailed yesterday for Hamburg.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 15.--Clara Louise Kellogg, assisted by the college glee club, gave an entertainment in the university course this evening.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 15.--The Court of Appeals having affirmed the decision of the court below and refused to reopen the case of William Neal, convicted of murder, Gov. Knott to-day signed the death warrant and fixed Friday, Feb. 27, for the execution.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15.--The House today, under a special order, proceeded to the consideration of the McPherson Funding bill. Mr. Wilkins, of Ohio, gave a brief statement of the features of the bill and the causes which made necessary the passage of some such measure.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15.--The proceedings of the United States Supreme Court to-day were as follows: No. 296--William H.C. Goode, appellant, vs. Benjamin Slusson, et al., from the Circuit Court for the Northern District of Ohio. On motion of John R. Bennett for appellees, dismissed per stipulation.
KORTI, Jan. 15.--Gen. Stewart's force reached the Howeiyatt Wells on Saturday, the 10th inst., obtained a supply of water, and resumed the march to Gakdul.

A special meeting of the First Ward Republican Association of Brooklyn was held last evening at No. 172 Montague-street. At the regular meeting in November Dr. George H. Atkinson was elected President. His death left Mr. F. A. Ward, Vice-President, presiding officer.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15.--The East-bound Classification Committee met here to-day and decided to make a new classification of east-bound freights.
A ballet of 30 dancers, led by Adele Cornalba, will be one of the chief attractions of the spectacle of "Michael Strogoff" at the Grand Opera House next week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15.--The President has modified the executive order of Nov. 5, 1883, as follows: The ratings of first, second, and third class machinist are abolished, and hereafter there will be one rating of machinist in the navy with the pay of $70 a month. New ratings are hereby established as follows: Boiler makers, $60 per month; water tenders, $38; oilers, $36; chief musician, $36.

FORT PLAIN, N.Y., Jan. 15.--Edward Underhood, a paper manufacturer, of Brown's Hollow, has assigned. Liabilities about $25,000; assets unknown. Fort Plain merchants lose largely.

MONTREAL, Jan. 16.--A large public meeting of unemployed workmen has been called for Tuesday night, when addresses will be made by leading merchants on the situation. NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 19.--Yesterday Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church was the scene of unusual excitement. The Rev. Dr. Robert A. Holland, the Rector, did not preach.
The Dartmouth College Association of New-York will hold its twenty-first annual dinner and reunion on Friday evening, Jan. 30, at Delmonico's.
NYACK, Jan.19.--A new post of the Grand Army of the Republic has been organized at Montgomery, with 24 members.
LONDON, Jan. 19.--The Victoria Woolen Mills at Batley, in Yorkshire, have been destroyed by fire. The loss is estimated at 150,000.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19.--The present indications are that the East-bound freight pool has gone to pieces. All of the Vanderbilt lines have left the pool, and, with the other roads, are carrying grain to New-York...

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 19.--Gov. Hill gave a hearing this afternoon to counsel for Sheriff Davidson, of New-York, on the charges against him which have been on file in the Executive Chamber for some time past.

The Young Men's Democratic Club held its first meeting lost evening in its new rooms, No. 9 West Twenty-fourth-street, which are handsomely furnished and will hereafter be open at all times for the accommodation of members.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., Jan. 19.--To determine the exact consumption of petroleum as a matter of prime importance to the oil trade, but owing to insufficient data, all figures hitherto current have been at best rough estimates, an elaborate report will be given to the...
HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 19.--The House of Representatives in its session to-night adopted unanimously a concurrent resolution offered by Dir. Robertson, of Allegheny, as follows:

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 19.--William H. Chadwick, late Cashier of the Pacific National Bank at Nantucket, overdrew his account $8,000, and his resignation was demanded last week. Mr. Chadwick has been Cashier six years, and his large operations in real estate have attracted...

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 19.--In February, 1883, James H. Welsh, of this city, filed through ex-Gov. Hubbard, his counsel, a petition in the Superior Court for a divorce from his wife, Emma L. Welsh. Mr. Welsh and his family lived in elegant style on Asylum Hill.
VICKSBURG, Miss., Jan. 19.--The high stage of the water and the continued rise of the Mississippi River is causing great alarm in this section.

Talks with various Senators show that while Mr. John Davis will undoubtedly be confirmed to the position on the bench of the Court of Claims, to which he has been nominated by President Arthur, it will hardly be by a unanimous vote.

Mrs. Schuyler Hamilton, who resides in an elegant mansion at No. 48 West Thirty-eighthstreet, reported to Inspector Byrnes, at Police Headquarters, that on Saturday afternoon last her house was robbed of $600 worth of silverware.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19.--Hezekiah Williams, a colored man, was up in court to-day. For some weeks he has been exhibited at a museum here as "the wild man from the jungles of Africa."

The representatives of the various anthracite coal companies met yesterday at the office of the Pennsylvania Coal Company and discussed the question of the proposed combination with the Pennsylvania Railroad Company.
HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 19.--There are suits on the docket of the United States Circuit Court, this city, brought by Morgan, Marston Co., of New-York, against several persons in...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19.--For several days the House Committee on the Payment of Pensions, Bounty, and Back Pay has been investigating the cause of the delay in the Pension Bureau in allowing pension claims. The meetings of the committee have been held with closed doors, but the committee has now made the investigation public.

The annual report of the Buffalo, NewYork and Philadelphia Railroad Company,which has just been issued, is prefaced by the minutes of the annual meeting held in Philadelphia last week, at, which the new funding scheme was ratified and the following resolution adopted:

In opening for the defense in the PatonHuntington case yesterday, Lawyer Francis N Bangs made the following extraordinary statements: "At the time the alleged contract between Huntington and the plaintiffs was made the press was terrorizing them.

A statement of "facts concerning the Spanish treaty" has just been sent to the United States Senate by the special committee recently appointed by the Chamber of Commerce to oppose the ratification of the treaty.
Robert Wareing, manager of a wellknown variety theatre in Hoboken, was requested by a man named Kaufman not to allow Samuel Kaufman, his son, a lad of 17, to enter the place.

At the annual meeting of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association, at St. Luke's Hospital, last evening, the Treasurer reported that collections for the year had so far amounted to $30,988 90, and that enough more had been...

Reference was made in these columns Sunday to the fact that Mr. Thomas had secured the refusal of the Academy of Music for a series of afternoons and evenings next season. Details of the project to which this step was a prelude may now be furnished.

An azure lake, surrounded by the greenest trees, and reflecting everything in the bluest manner, was the scene which stood at the back of the Academy of Music last night. It breathed of sweet pastoral life, the amiable Phyllis and the adoring Strephon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19, 1885. The jury in the case of Bell Mann, of Chicago, and Edward Kirkwood and Daniel Corrigan, of this city, indicted for presenting fraudulent claims through the Bureau of Medicine and Surgery of the Navy Department,... against all the prisoners. The jury had been locked up

The members of the Rev. T. De Witt Talmage's congregation almost filled the spacious Tabernacle, in Brooklyn, last night, on the occasion of the annual sale of pews, and they waited expectantly for the reverend gentleman to make his appearance.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Jan. 19.--The store of Julius Peuss, a prominent clothing merchant of Lockport, was closed up by the Sheriff this morning on unsatisfied judgments. This afternoon Peuss made an assignment to James Atwater.

Dr. Rudolf Tauszky, the insanity expert, was taken from Mount Sinai Hospital to the Yorkville Police Court yesterday. His young wife, Frances, whom he tried to kill, occupied a seat beside him, and his sister stood close by.

About eight hundred ladies who are identified with mission work in the Protestant Episcopal Church assembled in conference yesterday at the hall of the Young Women's Christian Association on East Fifteenth-street.
The spectacle of "Michael Strogoff," which has of late been represented throughout the country under the auspices of Mr. Haverly, was beheld at the Grand Opera House last evening.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 19.--To-day the seventysixth anniversary of the birthday of Edgar Allan Poe was made the occasion for carrying out a desire long entertained by the members of his family to bury by his side the remains of his wife, Mrs. Virginia Clemm Poe, who died at Fordham,...

CHICAGO, Jan. 20.--A young man named John H. Heyl, well dressed, and about 24 years old, on Jan. 3 swore out a warrant before Justice Hammer for the arrest of Harry Kemper, on a charge of assault and battery.

Sir Roderick Cameron, the noblemanmerchant, sent out 450 invitations to the ball he gave in honor of his daughter last night, and fully 400 guests rolled up in carriages to the family home at No.149 Second-avenue, amid the old-fashioned aristocracy of Stuyvesant-square.

The Hon. James Speed, of Kentucky, who was Attorney-General under Presidents Lincoln and Johnson, has addressed the following letter to Senator Maxey, of Texas, in relation to the stand taken by Gen. Grant in respect to favors granted soldiers of the Confederate Army after the surrender of Gen. Lee at Appomattox:...

Although there were several elections in different States to-day of United States Senators, the interest of members of Congress was greatest in the contest in the State of New-York. The result, as determined in the caucus last night, has given satisfaction to members of both parties here.

When Police Justice Solon B. Smith called the Republican County Committee to order last evening and suggested that a Chairman for the evening bechosen,William H. Townley, Chairman of the Executive Committee, nominated John D. Lawson.

The sanitary officials are apparently in an unhappy frame of mind over the recent discovery and publication in the newspapers of the typhus fever nest in the tenement houses at Nos. 555 and 557 West Thirty-second-street, and the disgustingly filthy condition of the houses in which the victims to the scourge were found.

There was a lively scene early yesterday morning on the sidewalk in front of Miller's hotel at Long Island City. A party of local politicians bad been drinking freely in the barroom during the night, and when Supervisor Joseph McLoughlin and ex-Police Captain Anthony S. Woods began to quarrel, "Tony" Miller, the ...
There is mourning in the Bowery, sorrow in Houston and Bleecker streets, and desolation in the dance halls of the slums.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 20.--Carter H. Harrison, Chicago's notorious Democratic Mayor, has withdrawn from the Senatorial race. He declared last week that he would throw up the sponge, but his friends urged him to hang on, and he came here to look the ground over. He found two Democrats who absolutely refused to vote for him.

Two hundred happy faces beamed at Delmonico's table last night, when the annual dinner of the Associate Alumni of the College of the City of New-York was held. The room, where so many sentiments have struggled with champagne was last night the scene of intense good-fellowship and unlimited conviviality.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Jan. 20.--Just before the opening of the New-Orleans Exhibition J.W. Slorah, of Saratoga, who has run English drags at that village during the past three seasons, started for New-Orleans with 15 horses and several drags. Two of his horses died in the South.
The eighth annual meeting of the Jewelers' League of the city of New-York was called to order in Masonic Hall at 7:30 o'clock last evening by President Gilbert T. Woglom.
LONDON, Jan. 20.--The latest mails from Madagascar state that a small body of volunteers, under an American officer, has run the blockade and reached Antananarivo, the capital.
Although the Diocese of Montreal possesses the largest cathedral in America, it was for many years a matter of sincere regret among local Roman Catholics that Montreal was entirely without relics.

ALBANY, Jan. 20.--The hotel corridors have resumed their wonted dullness. The visiting Congressmen, local politicians, and machinists have about all retired from the field, leaving its legitimate occupants in full possession.

Hugh Coyle and I.C. Davis were each presented with a handsomely engraved gold medal yesterday on behalf of the Actors' Fund and through its President, for their instrumentality in securing President-elect Cleveland's presence at the last benefit performance for the fund.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20.--President-elect Cleveland may not appreciate the fact, but he should know that even among some of the Republicans of the capital there is beginning to be some genuine concern lest he may not be considering seriously enough the business of making up his Cabinet.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 20.--No clue has yet been obtained as to the identity of the man whose body was found near this city yesterday. The report published in THE TIMES caused the New-York police authorities to telegraph for a photograph of the body, which was taken today.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Jan. 20.--The weather to-day was cold, bleak, and showery, and toward evening a drenching rain set in. Yet people went to the Exposition grounds and business was transacted as usual.

In a communication to the Mayor the Commissioners of Accounts, who have, at his request, been looking into the matter, have suggested what they consider a better method of paying interest coupons in the Finance Department than that which is now in use, and one which would prevent a repetition of anything like the "Carroll frauds."

SOUTHAMPTON, Long Island, Jan. 20.-- There is much excitement here over the capture this afternoon in the ocean between East Hampton and Amagansett of three monster right whales, known to whalemen as "two cows and a calf."
PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan 20.--The creditors of Oliver Brothers Phillips met this forenoon to discuss the affairs of the firm and to hear a report from them of their liabilities and assets.

Herman Schmidt, a New-Jersey farmer, was placed before the bar in the Court of Special Sessions yesterday, charged with carrying firearms and flourishing them in a dangerous manner while on the street.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 20.--According to the opinion handed down to-day by the Court of Appeals the East River Bridge Company is denied the right to seek a mandamus in the courts to restrain Hubert O. Thompson, as Commissioner or Public Works, from preventing them from carrying the approaches of the bridge across Chatham and Centre streets, and they will have to seek relief from the Legislature.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 20.--Reports come from Hocking Valley to-night that a large number of men were seen drilling near Longstreth yesterday, and an outbreak is feared in a day or two. It is also reported that a dynamite bomb was exploded at Longstreth to-night, but no damage resulted.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 20.--A mass meeting of the college was called this afternoon for the annual election of lacrosse officers, which resulted as follows: President--A.C. Smith; Secretary--F. Evans, Jr.; Treasurer--R.T.H. Halsey. Mr. C.B. Gamble wne re-elected Captain and W.R. Blakemore was made Second Captain. It was under Mr. Gamble's Captaincy that Princeton secured the lacrosse championship last year.

There is a new game of billiards called "Thirty-eight." It appears to have met with special favor among the many devotees of pool, and those who have grown weary of the incessant work at the pockets turn to "Thirty-eight" and find plenty of diversion.
"I hear that Smith has met with an accident. Do you know if he is seriously hurt?" "He must be. A doctor, a lawyer, and a minister have just gone to his house."

The Rev. Dr. Pullman submitted to the Trustees of the Church of the Saviour last evening the reasons that have led him to consider the acceptance of a call to the Universalist Church at Lynn, Mass. These reasons were stated in THE TIMES of Monday.

Argument was heard by Judge Andrews, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, on the motion on behalf of ex-Judge Hilton, A.L. Loomis, and others, for the continuance of the injunction restraining the Thirty-fourth-Street Railroad Company from laying its tracks in that street.

WASHINGTON, Jan.20.--The proceedings of the Supreme Court to-day were as follows: No. 1,115-- Alfred Sully, appellant, vs. James M. Drennan, et al.; No. 1,116--Alfred Sully, appellant, vs. William R. Maning, and No. 1,117--Alfred Sully, appellant, vs. William R. Matthews.

Mr. E.M. Bentley, of Cleveland, Ohio, of the Bentley-Knight Electric Railroad, in operation in that city, who is visiting here, says that the recent severe snowstorm in the West has tested the electric railroad system very thoroughly. It has been feared by some that a hard snowstorm would interrupt travel.

The action of the Mining Stock and National Petroleum Exchange in requesting its Governing Committee to amend the constitution so that securities listed in the Stock Excharge may be dealt in has caused much comment.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 20.--A white child, 5 or 6 weeks old, was discovered yesterday by an officer of the Rumane Society in a Chinese opium joint at No. 265 South Clark-street. The place, which is a filthy basement, was occupied by seven adult Chinese, one of whom was a woman, and all were engaged in smoking opium.

The list of entries for the Spring and Autumn meetings of the Coney Island Jockey Club is unusually full this year, and indicates that a highly interesting season of sport is in preparation for patrons of the turf.
HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 20.--The Legislature, both branches voting separately, to-day elected J. Donald Cameron to succeed himself in the United States Senate.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 20.--Mr. George Augustus Sala, the English journalist and correspondent, lectured to-night at the Academy of Music to a large audience. He was introduced by exSenator William Pinkney Whyte. His subject was "Wars, Revolution, and Tumult."

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20.--The Chamber of Commerce at its annual meeting to-day passed a resolution protesting against the confirmation of the Spanish-American treaty and strongly urging the ratification of the Nicarsguan treaty.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20.--The Farmers' Review, of this city, as a result of its reports from all the Western, Northwestern, and Southwestern States respecting the wheat situation, will publish the following: "From a very thorough and careful investigation of the Spring wheat situation we now incline to the opinion that, no matter what prices may rule in the Spring, be they ...

HAVANA, Jan. 15.--According to the statement published by the Director-General of the Treasury the collections at the Custom Houses of the island during the month of November, 1884, amounted to $975,065, against $1,301,752 for the corresponding month of 1883, showing a decrease of $326,687. A part of this decrease-- $173,209--was owing to the reductions in the Custom House tariff.

Thomas Barbour, one of Patereson's most prominent citizens, died yesterday afternoon at the residence of his son, William Barbour, in this city. The news of his death was received with surprise at his home in Paterson, as it was not generally known that he was in America at all, he having gone to Ireland two or three years ago, and he was hardly expected to return to this country.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20.--United States District Attorney Valentine was visited this morning by two gentlemen, one of whom was a man of medium height, rather slender, apparently about 60 years of age, whose face unmistakably showed evidence of recent great mental distress.
EVANSVILLE, IND., Jan. 20.--Two chicken thieves were shot here early this morning by police officers. They had been out in the suburbs and had a large number of fine chickens in bags on their backs.

Before he went to school last Monday morning, little Eddie Armstrong of No. 678 Greene-avenue, Brooklyn, was sent to a grocer's with $5 to pay a bill. He said that he lost $4 of the change, and his mother scolded him. Eddie turned on his heel and hurried off to school.

YORKVILLE, S.C., Jan. 20.--Few cases of suicide have been recorded among negroes in this country, especially by the bullet and for love. At King's Mountain, just across the line of this county in North Carolina, a negro named Bill Smith was deeply in love with a dusky damsel, Mary Ann Hoskins.

The Beekman Hill ladies who have organized themselves into a Health Protective Association for the purpose of getting rid of bad smells and other unhealthy nuisances arising from the stables and slaughter houses on the east side met at a church in Fiftieth-street yesterday and welded themselves more firmly together by adopting a formidable constitution.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20.--The Board of Managers of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad was in session for more than two hours today considering the plan of reorganization that was referred to it at the recent meeting of stockholders.
The Senate to-day confirmed the nominations of John Davis to be Judge of the Court of Claims and William A. Richardson to be Chief-Justice of the same court.

The Ways and Means Committee to-day ordered reported a bill introduced by Mr. Hewitt, of New-York, which, if adopted, will be of great benefit not only to NewYork merchants, but also to business men in all parts of the country. The bill amends section 3,019 of the Revised Statutes and provides:

NORFOLK, Va., Jan.20.--Information has been received here that the steamer Chesapeake, of the Virginia oyster navy, captured yesterday morning off Gwynn's Island, seven schooners engaged in illegal dredging for oysters. The schooners and their crews, nnmbering 68 men, were turned over to the Sheriff of Matthews County. No effort to escape was made except in one case, when a shot from the steamer quickly brought the escaping schooner to.

TRENTON, Jan. 20.--The session of the Senate this morning was the shortest on record, lasting only 10 minutes. It was long enough, however, to make the Democrats feel somewhat more jubilant than they have been since their votes nominated and elected Mr. Schenck their presiding officer. The only business transacted was the announcement of the standing committees, which are as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20.--A handsome young woman in a Pompeian red silk dress, a sealskin coat, and an old gold velvet bonnet, stood up near Judge Hare's bench in the Quarter Sessions Court to-day with a fancy basket of wickerwork on her arm.

ALBANY, Jan. 20.--The Court of Appeals decided to-day that the Tenement House Cigar bill, passed last Winter, is unconstitutional. The matter came before them on a test case brought by Peter Jacobs, who was arrested May 14, 1884, in New-York.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 20.--The City Council voted to-night to abandon the electric light for street illumination and to use gas and naphtha. Electricity has been used here two or three years. The new move is expected to make a saving of $7,000 or $8,000.
Shoals of telegraphic dispatches were piled up on the desk of Representative Chace, of Rhode Island, to-day. They were messages of congratulation upon his election to the United States Senate.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan.20.--The nineteenth annual convention of the New-York State Trades Assembly, which began here to-day, was opened by President Walter N. Thayer. The Assembly represents 125,000 workingmen of the State. President Thayer delivered his annual address, presenting a review of the work of the organization for the past year.

READING, Penn., Jan. 20.--Daniel M. Kaufman, dealer in millinery and fancy goods, made an assignment to-day for the benefit of creditors, who among others are New-York and Philadelphia parties. His stock is valued at from $7,000 to $10,000. Executions have been issued against him for $3,000.
SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Jan. 20.--About 3 o'clock on Monday morning six masked men entered Wood's gambling establishment on the main plaza and robbed the safe of over $4,000 in greenbacks and gold coin.

The gambling fraternity in this city received a blow between the eyes last evening from which they will not recover for many months to come. With his officers Inspector Byrnes descended upon 12 reputed gaming houses in the upper part of the city, and seized the largest and most valuable assortment of gaming implements and ...

CHICAGO, Jan. 20.--At 2:30 this morning, when the thermometer was 14 below zero, Officer Ryan, of the Cottage Grove-Avenue Station, patrolling his beat in the vicinity of Michigan-avenue and Twenty-ninth-street, was attracted by a form wandering about the open lot at that corner.

The steamship Denmark, of the National Line, arrived from London yesterday after a stormy passage which occupied 20 days. Strong westerly gales prevailed the entire passage. Heavy seas were shipped, but no damage was sustained. There are still several overdue European steamships, but these vessels have probably been merely detained by bad weather.

At the opening of yesterday's session of the Commissioners who are to determine whether a railroad should be built in Broadway, and, if one should be built, how it should be operated, counsel for the Broadway, Lexington and Fifth-Avenue Railroad Company announced that that corporation opposed both the Broadway Surface Railroad Company and the Broadway Railroad Company.

A flutter of excitement was caused in the Oil Exchanges yesterday forenoon by the circulation of a report that the McCalmount Oil Company had failed. This is one of the largest oil-producing companies in the country, and the announcement caused a serious drop in the oil market and a decline of half a point in the stock market.

The Standard Quartet Club, now in its seventh season, gave the third concert of the current series at Steek Hall last evening. To admit that the performances its members supply are always as satisfactory as could be wished would be to substitute flattery for commendation; in dealing with their entertainments, however, the fact must ...

GENEVA, N.Y., Jan. 20.--At a meeting of the Trustees of Hobart College this afternoon it was decided to erect a new library building adjoining the chapel to cost $15,000. A fund for that purpose has been subscribed. The plans for the building have been made and adopted and the work will be begun at once.

William M. Hoes, writing in explanation of his relations to the Tradesmen's National Bank and Mrs. Annie M.B. Halsey, respectively, says that prior to Anthony Halsev's death he was his attorney, and afterward he naturally became the adviser of his widow. Mr. Halsey was indebted to the bank on notes, partly secured by collateral.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20.--Two "double-header" freight trains came into collision on the "Nickel Plate," near Grand Crossing, about 6 o'clock this morning, instantly killing Charles Ellis, the engineer of engine No.306, of the north-bound train. The engine is a complete wreck and the three other engines are badly damaged.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20.--Dr. John Buchanan, who became notorious three years ago by issuing bogus medical diplomas, was again arrested to-day, together with a woman calling herself Dr. Rebecca Russell, who claims to be Buchanan's business partner.

TARRYTOWN, Jan. 20.--Mrs. Julia Horan, wife of Peter Horan, had her husband arrested to-day for an assault committed upon her on Monday morning, in which she narrowly escaped with her life. Horan keeps a liquor saloon on Orchard-street. About two years ago he had a difficulty there with a man named N.A. Julien, a carpenter, and gave him a severe beating.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 20.--A decision of general interest has been rendered by Judge Westbrook in reference to the extent of the powers vested in local town Boards of Assessors in New-York State.

GALWAY, Jan. 20.--Thomas Parry, who murdered his sweetheart, Miss Alicia Burns, stepdaughter of a Galway hotel keeper, in November last, was hanged here to-day. Parry was engaged to be married to Miss Burns, but she broke off the engagement.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20.--The stockholders of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company held their annual meeting to-day at the general office of the company.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20.--The committee, consisting of Presidents E.P. Wilbur, of the Lehigh Valley Railroad, and Joseph S. Harris, of the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company, and E.S. Pardee, representing shippers in the Lehigh Valley, which was appointed at the meeting of the anthracite coal interests in NewYork yesterday to consult with the representatives...

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 20.--The output of copper ore from the mines of Lake Superior for the year 1884 was as follows: Calumet and Hecla, 24,997 tons, being an increase of 4,372 tons over 1883; Quincy, 3,447; Franklin, 2,302; Osceola, 2,508; Atlantic, 2,199; Allouez, 1,371; Huron, 1,192; Central, 1,031; Peninsula, 865; ...

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 20.--A Methodist court of arbitration is now sitting in the chapel of the State-Street Methodist Church, in this city, with the Pastor, the Rev. Ensign McChesney, presiding. About six years ago Elisha Mors, of West Troy, was a stockholder in the New-York and Columbia Gold Mining Company.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 20.--Last evening, it seems, Henry V. Lucas and Chris. Von der Ahe, the respective Presidents of the Union and St. Louis Baseball Clubs, had a conference, Mr. Lucas calling at Mr. Von der Ahe's office to see what could be done toward an amicable arrangement for the admission of the Union Club into the league.
MONTREAL, Jan. 20.--The Hon. Justice Mathieu rendered judgment this morning in the Practice Court in the case of George Stephen and others against the Hon. Bradley Barlow and others.

Saloon keepers to the number of about 60, most of them members of the East Side Wine, Liquor, and Beer Dealers' Protective Union, met yesterday afternoon at Nogel's Hall, in First-street, drank beer and discussed the laws referring to their trade.

Mr. Bernard Gutwilling, of the firm of Gutwillig Schief, importers of silks and hosiery, at No. 89 Franklin-street, met with a terrtible accident, which will doubtless result fatally, at his place of business yesterday afternoon.

Mayor Grace recently called the attention of the Police Commissioners to the Vaudeville Theatre, at No.156 Hester-street, complaint against which had been made by Mr. Elbridge T. Gerry, President of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, and inclosed reports of visits made by officers of that society to the place.
Sehr. John R. Bergen, Parsons, from Havana 8 ds., for st. John, N.B., Jan. 20, 25 miles S.E. of Sandy Hook.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 20.--The iron trade is already showing some of the activity promised, and locally it bids fair to be strong and healthy in a very short time. The Union Rolling Mill, which has been idle for nearly three months, will start at its full capacity on Feb. 1, employing between 300 and 400 men.
LONDON, Jan. 20.--The papers this morning are agreed that the Cabinet council today has to consider the gravest Egyptian problem which has presented itself since the bombardment of Alexandria.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20.--Despite rumors to the contrary, there is little doubt that the Pennsylvania and Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Companies will agree to pool their bituminous coal business during the coming year.
ALBANY, Jan. 20.--The most important cases involving the interpretation of the State corporation tax law, now before the courts, were decided to-day by the Court of Appeals.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Jan. 20.--The lard rendering tank in the pork packing house of J. E. Booge Co. exploded this morning, tearing down that portion of the building. Very few men were about the tank at the time, but of these John O'Worrall, Joseph French, and John Keelers were instantly killed.

ALBANY, Jan. 20.--The annual convention of the National Guard Association of this State began to-day in the city Council Chambers. The association is composed of officers of the National Guard. Col. McLeer, of the Fourteenth Regiment, presided, and there were present a large number of well-known officers, including Gens. Shaler, Brownell, Graves, and R.S. Oliver, ...

BALTIMORE, Jan. 20.--The Right Rev. William Paret, the newly elected Protestant Episcopal Bishop of the Diocese of Maryland, paid his first official visit to Baltimore to-day, and to-night he opened a missionary conference in St. Mary's Chapel in the interest of colored people.

Eleanor Biglin and her brother-in-law, Bernard Biglin, the politician, were complainants in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday against G.C. Miller, a milk dealer at No. 414 East Eighty-second-street.

The Classis of New-York, Reformed Church, met yesterday afternoon in the chapel of Collegiate Church, Fifth-avenue and Twentyninth-street, the Rev. O.H. Walser presiding. The call extended by the Norfolk-Street Church to the Rev. Frederick Christian Erhardt, of Manchester, N.H., was approved.
PARIS, Jan. 20.--Advices from Tonquin report the arrival of more reinforcements of French troops. A general forward movement of the invading forces is expected to begin the end of the present month.

MARION, S.C., Jan. 20.--Perry Richardson, an aged white man and a paralytic, who lived alone in a small cabin in this county, was murdered a few days ago, it is believed, by a colored boy named Richard Davis, who is about 10 years old.

Business men who desire quick transmission of their letters from Washington to New-York will be glad when a new President shall provide Washington with a Postmaster who will pay attention to their wants.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 20.--The American Cranberry Growers' Association held its annual meeting at the State Capitol to-day.
MONTREAL, Quebec, Jan. 20.--The final arrangements are being completed for opening the carnival on Monday, the 26th inst. The official programme for that day is as follows:

At a meeting of the American Yacht Club last evening Capt. C.G. Lundborg, a retired naval officer, delivered an address on improvements in ship-building, designed to secure greater speed, safety, comfort, and carrying capacity.

The cloakmakers who have been so much agitated in New-York over the alleged defect in the tariff which allows the importation of cloaks to the injury of American manufacturers of those garments, have not been entirely neglected by the Ways and Means Committee.
An order to show cause why the Hoyt will case should not be placed on the calendar of the Surrogate's Court for a fixed date was returnable yesterday.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 20.--At the fifth annual convention of the American Merino Sheep Breeders' Association, held here to-day, the following officers were elected: President--Charles E. Shepherd, of Canandaigua; Vice-President-- ...

VICKSBURG, Miss., Jan. 20.--Capt. Frank Merrigald, president of the Yazoo Delta Timber Company, and a gentleman named J.F. Adams, filed suit to-day in the United States Circuit Court against the Pullman Palace Car Company for damages, placing the amount at $25,000 each.
The second perfermance of Mr. Booth at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre drew an audience as numerous and enthusiastic as that of Monday evening. The play was again "Othello," Mr. Booth appearing as the Moor.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 20.--Most skillfully planned burglaries in this city have been unraveled. On Jan. 1 a man giving the name of Robert Lang leased a small building in the rear of William Nicklis's clothing establishment, on Main-street, ostensibly for a willow were manufactory.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Jan. 20.--The strike instituted by the weavers at the Fall River manufactory yesterday terminated this morning, and help excepting fixers and second hands, were permitted to return to their places. There is no change in the situation at the Troy Mill.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Jan. 20.--The RudgerClawson polygamy case was argued in the Territorial Supreme Court to-day and taken under advisement. An open venire and the exclusion of Mormons from the jury are the points at issue.

ROME, Jan. 20.--News has been received that villages in the highlands of Piedmont and Savoy have been devastated by avalanches. Three villages in Piedmont, including the important village of Frassino, have been buried under avalanches from the Piedmontese Mountains.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Jan. 20.--It commenced raining lightly here about noon and continued until night. The track was heavy, but the races came off according to programme. Only about 400 spectators were present. Pools sold on the track about the same as last night.

Mr. Evarts's friends made him give up yesterday to them. He reached his office at the usual hour and staid there as late as ever, but from the time of arrival to departure he was not left an hour to himself.
Steamship Surrey, (Br.,) Driscoll, Patras, Prote, Zante, Catania, Palermo, Valencia, and Gibraltar 30 ds., with fruit to Seager Bros.

There was a large gathering at the Madison-Avenue Baptist Church, yesterday, to witness the marriage ceremony which united Miss Jennie Allen Kirk, daughter of Edward C. Kirk, to Oliver Benedict Bridgeman. The ushers were Messrs. Courtney King, H.P. Bishop, Harry A. Day, Clarence Goodby, J.W. Alexander, and Henry Tobey.

James Marshall, 30 years ago, gave to his brother, John Marshall, a farm of 400 acres, at Thorn Creek, Butler County, upon condition that he would go and live there. The offer was accepted, but no deed of the farm was ever issued to John Marshall.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 20.--An incendiary attempted to burn the Town Hall at Fairfield this morning. The blinds of two windows in the Town Clerk's office were stuffed with hay and then set on fire. Fortunately the fire was discovered before much damage had been done. All the town records and other valuable documents are kept in the building.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20.--Oliver P. Hazard was convicted to-day of forging the indorsement of Nathan Corwith, a millionaire metal dealer of Chicago, to a note for $5,500, and was sentenced to an imprisonment of three and a half years in the penitentiary.

BERLIN, Jan. 20.--To-day's session of the committee of the West African conference lasted four hours and was devoted to a discussion of Baron Lambermont's report regarding neutrality and the formalities to be observed by powers annexing African territory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20.--The Secretary of War has decilned to order a court-martial for the trial of Chief Signal Officer Hazen on the charges preferred by Lieut. Garlington, and has decided to take no further action in regard to the Greely relief expedition.

Two or three different committees representing the operators, linemen, and other employes of the Bankers and Merchants' Telegraph Company, called upon the Receivers of that corporation yesterday and requested an answer to their petition for an immediate payment of their salaries in cash.

President King said yesterday that the statement that the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company had been shut off from the use of the Jefferson branch of the Erie, over which it sent its west-bound coal, was absolutely untrue. President Olyphant, of the Delaware and Hudson, said he had heard of no such thing.

Garret Campton and his 16-year-old wife lived at No. 408 East Fifty-fourth-street until the 12th inst., when they removed to No. 251 East Fifty-fourth-street. They left behind them a sadiron, a washtub, and a baby. VICKSBURG, Miss., Jan. 20.--From passengers arriving here by the Vicksburg, Shreveport and Pacific Railroad to-day news of a case of fatal shooting is learned, which occurred at Rayville, La. Mr.Jules P. Gilley and Mr. Arbro had some misunderstanding in regard to business matters, which resulted in the former being fatally shot by the latter.

It is not improbable that some of our eagle-eyed observers have actually seen the snow cap surrounding the poles of our fair celestial neighbor. Ever since the invention of the telescope Venus has been a favorite object for telescopic observation.

In the annual report the managers of the Society for the Reformation of Juvenile Delinquents have just sent the Legislature--the sixtieth since the organization of the society-- especial stress is laid upon the great pecuniary loss to the House of Refuge which will be caused by the recent legislation upon the system of contract labor in the State institutions.

Smoke and flame burst from the doors and windows of the ancient Bridge-Street African Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, at 3:30 o'clock yesterday morning. The building, which is of brick, with a large wooden porch and pillars in the front, burned very rapidly, and in a very short time what remained was merely a shell.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 20.--The pottery trouble here continues without perceptible change, although it is reported that the dissension in the Manufacturers' Association are more serious than were at first believed. Six of the bosses are employing their hands at the old rates, and it is stated openly that several members who voted for the new reduced list are wavering in their obedience to the leaders of the movements.
Testimony recently given before a committee of the House throws a great deal of light upon the pension claim business as it is carried on in Washington.

The Association of Exempt Firemen held its annual meeting in Caledonian Hall, in Horatio-street, last evening, and re-elected the following officers: President--Zophar Mills; Vicepresident--David Milliken, Jone R. Platt; Recording Secretary--George W. Wheeler; Financial Secretary--Francis Hagadorn; Treasurer --James Y. Watkins.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Jan. 20.--James Blythe, who is now serving a five-months sentence in the County Jail at New-Bedford, for being a common drunkard, has just fallen heir to $68,000. A few months ago a millionaire uncle died intestate in San Francisco.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20.--Capt. Dewey, the Canadian Post Office Inspector, who is in this city to try and induce young Campbell, who is alleged to have been in a conspiracy to rob the Canadian mails, to return to the Dominion and "squeal" on his accomplices, will return to Toronto to-morrow without having accomplished his mission, unless young Campbell voluntarily appears in the meantime.
The Court of Appeals of this State handed down decisions yesterday in three cases of special interest to the people of this city.

Miss Adele Margulies will give a concert with the co-operation of Mr. Thomas's orchestra, at Steinway Hall, on Friday evening.

LONDON, Jan. 20.--Mr. John Bright has published a letter in the form of a pamphlet devoted to a consideration of the effect likely to be produced by the extension of the franchise which has been brought about by the Franchise bill.

The Larchmont Yacht Club will meet at Delmonico's to-night to hear the report of a committee appointed to revise the constitution, by-laws, and sailing rules. Still another panic was caused at School No. 2, in Jersry City, by a false alarm of fire yesterday.

The family of Mr. Hugh Reavey, a lawyer who has an office at No. 102 Chambers-street and lives at No. 145 West Forty-fourth-street, were alarmed and puzzled yesterday over a mysterious attempt which was made early in the morning to burn their residence.
Nearly all of the sents on the floor of Association Hall were filled with men last night upon the occasion of the eleventh annual meeting of the New-York Society for the Suppression of Vice.

WICHITA, Kan., Jan. 20.--In the United States Court to-day Nellie C. Bailey was acquitted of the charge of the murder of a wealthy Englishman named Bothamley, with whom she was traveling in the Indian Territory about a year ago. The defendant maintained that Bothamley shot himself.

Mayor GRACE has made public a statement of his opinions upon the excise law. The subject is not strictly in the line of the Mayor's duties as an executive officer.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Jan. 20.--The gold and silver mines which, it is alleged, have and now are being unearthed on and at the base of the Shawangunk Mountain, in Ulster County, notably so at points near Ellenville, have induced prospectors to look for valuable ore beds at other points on the range and in the Catskill and Plattekill Mountains.
