The financial report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the quarter ending March 31, 1885, was issued yesterday.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 12.--William H. Moore, a laborer, aged 45 years, living in the suburbs, went out on the railroad last night to pick up coal, and this morning his dead body was found with wounds of such a character that foul play is suspected. KINGSTON, N.Y., March 12.--The sequel to an Ulster County elopement has attracted much attention before the County Court and Court of Sessions, Judge W.S. Kenyon presiding, now sitting in this city. James Delancey is a cripple and he used a crutch. His wife is prepossessing.

At the Fifth-Avenue Theatre last evening the Ideal Opera Company presented Varney's comic opera "The Musketeers." That this work should be unfamiliar to the New-York public is one of the peculiar facts in the history of comic opera in this city.

Mgr. Thomas S. Preston's series of Lenten sermons are, as usual, filling the Church of St. Ann, in East Twelfth-street, to its utmost capacity. ALBANY, March 18.--The Committee on General Laws gave a hearing to-day to a large number of persons interested in the bill introduced by Mr. Roesch relative to co-operative and beneficiary associations.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., March 18.--At 12 o'clock last night the mercury was several degrees below zero. The frigidity of the weather, however, did not prevent a party of young men from assembling in Jay-street. They were members of the Freshman Class of Union College.

RICHMOND, Va., March 18.--The interest here in the tragic death death of Miss Fanny Lilian Madison, the pretty governess, continues. Several new developments in the case have come to light to-day which will materially aid in solving the mystery.
WASHINGTON, March 18, 1885. The Senate in executive session this afternoon con firmed the nomination of Joseph S. Miller to be Commissioner of Internal Revenue, vice Evans removed.

BALTIMORE, March 18.--Secretary Manning has elevated one of Baltimore's notorious citizens to a conspicuous place, and at the same time caused a political convulsion in Maryland the effects of which remain to be seen.

The "Boston Ideals" gave two performances at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre yesterday. The first occurred in the afternoon, and "The Mascot" was sung. The second took place in the evening, and "Fatinitza" was represented. Audran's operetta is scarcely entitled to figure in the repertoire of a company capable of such good lyric work as the Ideals.

Gordon W. Burnham, one of the most widely known of the millionaires of this city, died at his residence, No. 128 Fifth-avenue, at 7:30 last evening, of pneumonia, after an illness of several days. Mr. Barnham was conscious to the end, and the last act of his life was to give a parting blessing to his two sons.

Mme. Modjeska's engagement to Mr. Henry E. Abbey in England is to cover a period of 13 weeks, and is to include London and a number of the largest provincial cities. Mr. Abbey is now engaging the company to support his star, and a number of people have already been definitely selected.

Perhaps nineteen reading people out of twenty, upon noticing the simple announcement of the death of Miss SUSAN WARNER, would be moved to inquire who Miss SUSAN WARNER was that her death should be made the subject of a press dispatch.

J.C. Clarke was re-elected President of the Illinois Central Railroad by the Directors yesterday, and Mr. S. Fish was re-elected VicePresident. SYRACUSE, March 18.--War Chief Ta-hoga-ous was accepted this afternoon at the Onondaga Indian reservation, six miles from this city, by a Grand Council of the Six Nations, as a member of the Board of Chiefs, and is now competent to participate in the most high and mighty deliberations.

At the last meeting of the committee on the charges against the Rev. George Guirey, formerly Pastor of the Willis-Street Baptist Church, in Paterson, N.J., the accused and his counsel withdrew, as the committee declined to admit in evidence a number of affidavits submitted by the defense.

SUAKIN, March 18.--A general advance toward Tamas will be made next Friday. Spies continue to report that the Amarar tribe of Arabs will desert El Mahdi and join the British at the first favorable opportunity.

PITTSBURG, March 18.--The situation among the striking miners is practically unchanged. An informal meeting of operators was held at the Coal Exchange to-day for the purpose of discussing the situation. No definite action was taken, and the meeting adjourned until Saturday next.

WASHINGTON, March 23.--No step that has been taken by the new Administration excites so much interest here or carries so much conviction of the earnestness of its professions in favor of a more economical and businesslike conduct of the public service than the proposed reorganization of the force of the Treasury Department.

CHICAGO, March 23.--Cattle were bought little cheaper to-day, but not as much as there was danger of their doing at the opening of business in the morning, but enough cheaper to make it a losing "deal" for a majority of owners.

Some weeks ago the Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company issued an order forbidding its gatemen, under penalty of dismissal, to quit their posts during their hours of duty. The night men are relieved at 7 A.M and the day men at 7 P.M. Under this order the gatemen were compelled to eat their dinners in the open air and to stand at their posts for 12 hours.

The President's nominations for foreign Ministers are excellent. For the three chief European Missions and for Mexico he has named four gentlemen of high standing, of ability, and of special qualifications for the work they are to do. They are all well-trained lawyers.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 23.--But few members of the General Assembly were in the city to-day, but the news of Mr. Pendleton's nomination and confirmation as Minister to Germany was eagerly discussed, and the general verdict is that Mr. Cleveland has made no mistake in honoring the author of the Civil Service Reform bill.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 23.--Justice Stanley Matthews has just submitted a decision in the important suit brought by the Hocking Valley and Toledo Railroad against the Ohio Central for net profits derived by the Ohio Central through increased shipments of coal over the latter road on account of the strike in the Hocking Valley.

ELGIN, Ill., March 23.--The business troubles of Charles W. Gould, the extensive butter and cheese dealer, prove to be more serious than was at first suspected. Mr. Gould, who has been a pioneer in the dairy business hereabout, was the largest individual manufacturer of butter and cheese in the United States.

Opponents of the system of new parks provided for by the act of 1884 gathered at Chickering Hall last evening to the number of several hundred, and expressed their opinions on the subject in an earnest and at times enthusiastic meeting.

WASHINGTON, March 23.--A decision was rendered by the Supreme Court of the United States today in the series of five cases known as the polygamy suits, which were brought by certain Mormon citizens of Utah for the purpose of getting a judicial decision as to the power of the Board of Commissioners or Canvassers, appointed under the so-called Edmunds act of March 22, 1882, to supervise elections in that Territory.

TRENTON, March 23.--At the session of the Assembly this evening Gov. Abbett made Saturday's fire in the State Capitol Building the text of a special message. In it he says that the foundation walls of the northern part of the building have been so badly undermined by water as to make the rebuilding of all that part of the structure necessary.

Gen. Grant resumed work on his book yesterday morning, and added several pages to the manuscript for the second volume. The work was attended with a good, deal of difficulty, for his inability to get sufficient sleep has made him languid. He has remarked quite often of late that he feels oppressed with a desire to sleep which he cannot gratify.

TRENTON, March 24.--This has been one of the tamest legislative days of the session, and yet one of the busiest. Both morning and afternoon sessions were mainly devoted to the consideration of numerous local bills, of interest only to the localities which they sought to benefit.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 24.--The Hon. Donald Smith, one of the Directors of the Hudson's Bay Company, speaking of one of the company's vessels, the Prince of Wales, states that she arrived at Moose Factory, James's Bay, Sept. 27 last, and, taking on a cargo of furs valued at $250,000, sailed for London Oct. 3.

ALBANY, March 25,--In the Court of Appeals to-day the case of Jool W. Mason against John McClavo came up on appeal from judgment of the General Term for defendant to determine the controversy concerning the Police Commissionership of New-York.

BUFFALO, March 25.--For nearly five years the First Presbyterian Society of Buffalo, the parent of the Presbyterian churches of this city, has been divided against itself on the question whether another church edifice should not be secured further up town and the old church abandoned and sold.

The delightful change in the weather was taken instant advantage of yesterday by immense throngs of shoppers. So many of these made the store of the Stern Brothers, in West Twenty-third-street, their destination that it was crowded to the doors.

Yesterday was opening day at Lord Taylor's, Broadway and Twentieth-street, for the exhibition of costumes, cloaks, and bonnets. The display was one of the finest ever presented by the house, and in point of numbers and sales the opening was fully up to the usual success.

As a dealer in lumber years ago and as President of the Rock Island Road for a long time Charles W. Durant accumulated a large fortune, to which be added while carrying on business as a banker in this city.

ALBANY, March 26.--The Feedom of Worship bill came up for final passage in the Senate to-day. It was the purpose of its Democratic friends to push it to a passage at once, being spurted on to this by the vigorous assistance of Senator Gibbs, its parent and chief Republican supporter.

Billy Madden's athletic hall, in East Thirteenth-street, was crowded last evening when a competition for pugilists, whose weight did not exceed 140 pounds, took place. The prize was a handsome diamond pin.

SUAKIN, March 26.--The convoy of the Grenadier Guards, under command of Gen. Graham, accompanied the Shropshire, Surrey, and Sikhs (Indian) regiments this morning on their departure for Tamai, as far as Gen. McNeill's zereba.

DUBLIN, March 26.--The Nationalists of County Wexford have raised a fund of 1,200 to pay their local members of Parliament.

SPRINGFIELD, March 26.--The hope that the Illinois Legislature would to-day elect Gen. Logan United States Senator failed of realization. He received 101 votes on two of four ballots, being two short of enough to elect.

TRENTON, March 26,--The Constitutional Convention bill came up in the House again this morning. Every member, unless excused, except Mr. Bell, of Newark, was in his seat.

WASHINGTON, March 26.--Notwithstanding the pressure upon the President to induce him to decide the question about the New-York Post Office adversely to the reappointment of Mr. Pearson the President, considering the case with the greatest care, has not yet made up his mind.

ALBANY, March 26.--The hearing on the New-York Parks bill was continued before the members of the Cities Committee of the two houses this afternoon. E.B. Honsdale and Joseph L. Wood spoke against Mayor Grace's plan to restrict the now parks to territory comprised in the limits of New-York City.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., March 26.--Reports of deer and other wild animals having been driven in from the woods to farms and even villages in this county by the intensely cold weather and hunger have been received nearly every day during the past week.

WINNIPEG, Mamitoba, March 24.--Dispatches from the West show that numerous companies are being organized for defense at all points along the line of the railway. The whole country is in an uproar. Farmers are drilling for service.
